Moses' sister said to Pharaoh's guards: Shall I direct you to a family who will breastfeed him, take care of him, take care of him, and serve him?

Pharaoh's wife was very happy about this, and asked her to bring a wet nurse. Musa's sister returned and brought his mother. His mother breastfed him and he suckled. Pharaoh's wife rejoiced and said: "Take him until his breastfeeding period is over and return him to us after that, and we will give you a great reward for raising him." Thus, God Almighty returned Moses to his mother so that her eyes would be comforted, her heart would be calm, and she would not be sad, and so that she would know that God’s promise is true and that His words, Glory be to Him, are carried out despite anything. Despite everything.

Moses’ upbringing in the house of Pharaoh:

Moses' mother finished breastfeeding him and handed him over to the house of Pharaoh. He was loved by everyone. No one saw him but loved him. And here he is, in the greatest palaces of the world, being raised by God’s protection and care. Moses' upbringing began in the house of Pharaoh. This house included the greatest educators and teachers at that time. In its days, Egypt was the greatest country on earth. Pharaoh was the most powerful king in the land, and it was natural that his palace included the greatest trainers, intellectuals, and educators in the land. Thus, the wisdom of God Almighty wanted Moses to receive the greatest education and to be taught by the greatest teachers, and for all of this to take place in the house of his enemy, with whom he would clash later in implementation of the Creator’s will.

Moses grew up in the house of Pharaoh. Moses knew that he was not a son of Pharaoh, but rather one of the children of Israel. He saw how Pharaoh's men and his followers persecuted the children of Israel...and Moses grew up and reached his maturity... (And he entered the city while some of its people were unaware of it) and began to walk around it. He found a man of Pharaoh's followers fighting with a man from the children of Israel, and the weak man sought help from him, so Moses intervened and removed the unjust man with his hand, killing him. Moses was very strong, and he did not intend to kill the oppressor. He only wanted to remove him, but this blow killed him. Then Moses was surprised by him, and he had died, and said to himself: (This is the work of Satan. He is a clear and misleading enemy.) Moses prayed to his Lord: (He said, “My Lord, I have wronged myself, so forgive me.”) And God Almighty forgave him, (Indeed, He is the Forgiving, the Merciful).

Moses became (in the city, afraid and anticipating). This was the condition of Moses, the condition of a man being pursued. He was afraid, expecting evil at every step, and he was on the lookout, paying attention to the most subtle and hidden movements.

Moses promised not to be a supporter of criminals. He will not intervene in quarrels between criminals and rioters to defend any of his people. While he was walking, Moses was surprised by the same man who had saved him yesterday, calling him and pleading with him today. The man was involved in a fight with an Egyptian. Moses realized that this Israelite was a troublemaker. I realize that he is a fan of quarrels. Moses shouted at the Israelite, rebuking him, saying: “You are a clear linguist.” Moses said his word and rushed towards them, wanting to attack the Egyptian. The Israeli thought that Moses would strike him down. Fear of Moses prompted him to cry out for his mercy, and reminded him of the Egyptian who had killed him yesterday. So Moses stopped, his anger subsided, and he remembered what he had done yesterday, and how he had asked for forgiveness, repented, and promised not to be a supporter of criminals. Moses turned back and went away asking his Lord for forgiveness.

The Egyptian, who was quarreling with the Israeli, realized that Moses was the killer of the Egyptian whose body they found yesterday. None of the Egyptians knew who the killer was. This Egyptian spread the news throughout the city. Moses' secret was revealed and his matter became clear. A faithful Egyptian man came running from the farthest part of the city. He advised Moses to leave Egypt, because the Egyptians intended to kill him.

The Holy Qur’an did not mention the name of the man who came to warn Moses. We believe that he was an important Egyptian man, as he was aware of a conspiracy being hatched against Moses from high levels. If he had been an ordinary person, he would not have known. The man knows that Moses did not deserve to be killed for his sin yesterday. He killed the man by mistake. His punishment should be imprisonment at the maximum.

But the leaders and elite of the people, who seemed to hate Moses because he was from the children of Israel, and because he had survived the year in which every male born was killed, found this an appropriate opportunity to get rid of Moses, because he had killed the Egyptian, so he deserved to be killed.

Moses left Egypt immediately. Afraid, he turns around, listens, and waits. In his heart is a supplication to God (Lord, save me from the wrongdoing people). The people were truly unjust. Don't they want to apply the penalty of premeditated murder to him, when he did nothing more than extend his hand and remove a man, killing him by mistake?

Moses left Egypt in a hurry. He did not go to Pharaoh's palace, did not change his clothes, did not take food for the road, and did not prepare his travel gear. He did not have an animal to carry him on its back. He was not in a convoy. He only left as soon as the believing man came to him and warned him about Pharaoh and advised him to leave. Choose an untrodden path and follow it. He entered the desert directly and headed where God had destined him to go. Moses was not going to a specific place. This is his first time going out and crossing the desert alone.

Moses in Midian:

He kept walking like a stalker until he reached a place. This was the place he owed. He sat and rested at a great well from which people watered their animals. He was afraid all the time that Pharaoh would send someone behind him to arrest him.

No sooner had Moses reached Midian than he threw himself under a tree and rested. He was overcome with hunger and fatigue, and his sandals fell off after they had melted from the hardship of walking on sand, rocks, and dirt. He had no money to buy new shoes. He had no money to buy food or drink. Moses noticed a group of shepherds watering their sheep, and he found two women who were keeping their sheep mixed with the people’s sheep. Moses felt something like an inspiration that the two girls needed help. He approached them and asked if he could help them with anything.

One of them said: We are waiting for the shepherds to finish watering their sheep so we can water them.
Moses asked: Why don't you water?
The other said: We cannot compete with men.
Moses was amazed because they were tending sheep. Men are supposed to herd sheep. This is a tedious and tiring task that requires vigilance.
Moses asked: Why do you feed the sheep?
One of them said: Our father is an old man, and his health does not allow him to go out to graze every day.
Moses said: I will give you water to drink.

Moses walked toward the water. He watered the sheep for them with the rest of the shepherds. In a narration, the shepherds placed a huge rock at the mouth of the well after they had finished, and only a number of men could move it. So Moses lifted the rock alone. He watered the sheep for them, returned the rock to its place, left them, and went back to sitting under the shade of the tree. At that moment, he remembered God and called to him in his heart: (My Lord, I am in need of whatever good You have sent down to me.)

The two girls returned to their father, the sheikh.

The father asked: Did you come back unusually quickly today?!
One of them said: We met a generous man who watered the sheep for us.
The father said to his daughter: Go to him and tell him: (My father is calling you) to give you (the reward for what you watered for us).

One of the girls went to Musa, stood before him, and told him her father's message. So Moses got up and looked at the ground. He did not water the sheep for them to get a reward from them, but rather he helped them for the sake of God. However, he felt inside him that God was the one guiding his feet, so he got up. The girl walked in front of him. The wind blew and hit her dress, so Moses lowered his gaze in shame and said to her: I will walk in front of you, and you show me the way.

They arrived at the Sheikh. Some commentators said that this sheikh is Prophet Shuaib. He lived long after the death of his people. It was said that he was Shuaib's nephew. It was said that he was his cousin, and it was said that he was a believing man from the people of Shuaib who believed in him. We know nothing more than that he is a good sheikh.

The Sheikh gave him food and asked him: Where did it come from and where is it going? Moses told him about his story. The Sheikh said: (Do not be afraid, you have escaped from the unjust people). This country does not belong to Egypt, and they will not reach you here. Moses was reassured and got up to leave.

The sheikh's daughter said to her father in a whisper: (O father, hire him. Indeed, the best of those you hire is the strong and trustworthy.)
The father asked her: How did you know that he was strong?
She said: He alone lifted a rock that only a number of men could lift. He asked her: How did you know that he was honest?
She said: He refused to walk behind me and walked in front of me so as not to look at me while I was walking. The whole time I was talking to him, he kept his eyes on the ground out of modesty and politeness.

The sheikh returned to Moses and said to him: O Moses, I want to marry one of my daughters to you, provided that you work in herding sheep for me for eight years. If you complete ten years, then because of your generosity, I do not want to tire you. (You will find me, God willing, among the righteous.) Musa said: This is an agreement between you and me. God is a witness to our agreement. Whether I spend eight years or ten years, I am free to go.

Many people delve into a maze of stories and novels about which of the two daughters of the sheikh he married, and for which two periods he served. What is certain is that Musa married one of the sheikh’s daughters. We don't know who she was, nor what her name was. These matters were silent about in the Qur’anic context. However, based on the nature of Moses, his generosity, his prophecy, and his being one of the people of resolve. We see that he spent the longest period. This is confirmed by the hadith of Ibn Abbas, may God be pleased with them both. Thus, Moses lived serving the sheikh for ten full years.

Moses and herding sheep:

Musa's work was limited to going out at dawn every day to graze and water the sheep.

Let us pause here and reflect. The divine power moved the steps of Moses - peace be upon him - step by step. From the time he was a baby in the cradle until this moment. She threw him into the sea so that Pharaoh's family could pick him up. She bestowed upon him the love of Pharaoh's wife, so that he could grow up in the care of his enemy. He entered the city while some of its people were unaware of it, to kill a person. A faithful man from Pharaoh's family was sent to him to warn him and advise him to leave Egypt. I accompanied him on the desert road from Egypt to Midian, and he was alone and pursued without food or preparation. I brought him together with the great sheikh to rent him these ten years. Then he returns and receives the assignment.

This is a long line of care and guidance, before calling and commissioning. Experience care, love and pampering. The experience of rushing under the pressure of pent-up rage, and the experience of remorse and seeking forgiveness. And experience fear and stalking. And the experience of alienation, loneliness and hunger. And the experience of service and feeding sheep after a life of palaces. What permeates these huge experiences are small experiences, feelings, thoughts, perceptions and knowledge. In addition to what God gave him when he reached his peak of knowledge and wisdom.

The mission is a huge and arduous task, and its holder needs a huge amount of experiences, awareness, and knowledge, in addition to God’s revelation and guidance. The message of Moses is a great assignment, as it is sent to the arrogant tyrant Pharaoh, the most powerful king of his time, and the most arrogant on earth. He was sent to rescue a people who had drunk from the cups of humiliation until they continued to taste it. Saving people like these is hard work.

The experience of ten years came to separate the life of palaces in which Moses - peace be upon him - grew up from the life of hard effort in the call and its difficult costs. Palace life has a special atmosphere and traditions. As for the message, it is the suffering of masses of people, including the rich and the poor, the polite and the rough, the strong and the weak, among them and in them. The message has its costs, including hardship and detachment at times, and the hearts of people of palaces often do not tolerate harshness, deprivation, and hardship for long.

When the soul of Moses - peace be upon him - completed its trials and completed its training, with this last experience in the abode of Ghura. Divine power led his steps once again, taking him back to his landing place, the headquarters of his family and people, and his field of work. Thus we see how Moses was created in the eyes of God, and how he was prepared to receive the commission.

Moses' return to Egypt:

Do you know what thought Moses had when he returned to Egypt, after the expiration of the term, when he left it fearful and anticipating? And make him forget the danger that awaits him there, even though he has killed a soul there? And there is Pharaoh who was conspiring with the leaders of his people to kill him?

It is God's power that transmits all his steps. Perhaps this time she led him by an innate inclination toward family, clan, and homeland. And he made him forget the danger from which he fled, alone and expelled. To perform the task for which he was created.

Musa went out with his family and walked. The moon disappeared behind swarms of thick clouds and darkness prevailed. The lightning and thunder intensified, the sky rained, and the cold and darkness increased. Moses got lost while walking. Musa stood bewildered and shivering from the cold among his people. Then he raised his head and saw a great fire burning in the distance. His heart was suddenly filled with joy. He told his family: I saw a fire there.

He ordered them to sit there until he went to the fire. Perhaps he would bring them news from it, or find someone to ask him about the path and guide him to it, or bring them some burning wood to warm them.

Moses moved toward the fire. Musa quickly walked to warm himself. His right hand holds his staff. His body is wet from the rain. He kept walking until he reached a valley called Tuwa. Notice something strange in this valley. There was neither cold nor wind. There is a great still silence. Moses approached the fire. No sooner had he approached it than it was called: (Indeed, blessed are those in the Fire and those around it, and Glory be to God, Lord of the Worlds).

Moses looked into the fire and found a green tree. The more the fire burns, the greener the tree becomes. The tree is supposed to turn black as it burns. But the fire increases and the green color increases. The tree was on a western mountain to his right, and the valley in which he stood was Wadi Tuwa.

Then the earth shook with reverence and awe as God Almighty called out: O Moses!

Moses replied: Yes.

God Almighty said: Indeed, I am your Lord

Moses' trembling increased and he said: Yes, Lord.

God Almighty said: Then take off your shoes, for you are in the holy valley of Tuwa.

Musa knelt down, his whole body shaking, and took off his shoes. The Truth, Glory be to Him, the Most High, returned, saying: And I have chosen you, so listen to what is revealed. (13) Indeed, I am God. There is no god but Me, so worship Me and establish prayer in remembrance of Me. (14) Indeed, The Hour is coming. I have almost concealed it, so that every soul may be rewarded for what it strives. (15) So do not turn you away from it who does not believe in it and follows his own desires and is ruined. (16) (Taha)

Moses' body twitched more as he received divine revelation and listened to his Lord speaking to him.

The Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, said: And what is that in your right hand, O Moses?

Musa's astonishment increased. It is God Almighty who is speaking to him, and God knows better than him that he is holding his staff. Why then does God ask him if he knows more than him?! There is no doubt that there is a higher wisdom for this.

Moses answered: He said, “They are my staffs, on which I lean and beat my sheep with them, and with them I have other purposes.”

God Almighty said: Cast it, O Moses

Moses threw the stick from his hand, and his astonishment increased. He was surprised that the stick suddenly turned into a huge, massive snake. The snake started moving quickly. Moses could not resist his fear. He felt his body shaking with fear. Then Musa turned around in fear and started running. He had barely taken two steps before God called him: O Moses, do not be afraid, for the Messengers do not fear.

Musa turned around and stood up again. The stick was still moving. The snake was still moving.

God Almighty said to Moses: Take her and do not be afraid. We will restore her to her former way of life.

Moses extended his hand to the serpent, trembling. No sooner had he touched it than it turned into a stick in his hand. The divine command was issued to him again: Place your hand in your pocket and it will come out white without any blemish, and close your wings of terror to you.

Moses put his hand in his pocket and took it out, and it was shining like the moon. Moses became more emotional about what was happening, so he placed his hand on his heart as God commanded him, and his fear completely disappeared.

Musa was reassured and remained silent. God issued an order to him after these two miracles - the miracle of the staff and the miracle of the hand - to go to Pharaoh to call him to God gently and gently, and to command him to expel the children of Israel from Egypt. Moses expressed his fear of Pharaoh. He said that he killed one of them and was afraid that they would kill him. He begged God to send his brother Aaron with him. God reassured Moses that he would be with them, listening and seeing, and that Pharaoh, despite his cruelty and tyranny, would not harm them. God made Moses understand that He is the victor. Moses prayed and prayed to God to open his heart to him, ease his affairs, and give him the ability to call to Him. Then Moses returned to his family after God had selected him and chosen him as a messenger to Pharaoh. Moses went down with his family to Egypt.

Only God knows what thoughts crossed Moses' mind as he headed towards Egypt. The time of contemplation has ended, the days of rest have ended, and the difficult times have finally come, and here is Moses carrying the trust of truth and going on to confront with it the oppression of the greatest and most powerful titans of his time. Moses knows that the Pharaoh of Egypt is a tyrant. He knows that the children of Israel will not hand him over without a struggle. He knows that he will take a position of denial, pride, and neglect regarding his calling. God Almighty commanded him to go to Pharaoh. To call him gently and kindly to God. God revealed to Moses that Pharaoh would not believe. Let Moses leave him alone. Let him focus on releasing the children of Israel and stopping their torture. God Almighty said to Moses and Aaron: (Then go to him and say, “Indeed, we are the messengers of your Lord, so send with us the Children of Israel and do not torture them.”) This is the specific task. It is a mission that will encounter thousands of obstacles. Pharaoh tortures the children of Israel, enslaves them, assigns them more work than they can handle, keeps their women alive, slaughters their children, and disposes of them as if they were special property that he inherited with the king of Egypt. Moses knew that the Egyptian regime was based, in its basic structure, on enslaving the children of Israel and exploiting their work, effort, and energies in the state. Did the Pharaoh go too far in building the basic state simply and easily? Ideas came and went, shortening the hardship of the road. The curtain was raised on the confrontation scene.

Confronting Pharaoh:

Moses confronted Pharaoh with kindness and gentleness, as God commanded him. He told him about God. About His mercy and His paradise. About the necessity of uniting him and worshiping him. He tried to awaken his human aspects in conversation. He hinted to him that he owned Egypt, and that he could own Paradise if he wanted. All he has to do is fear God. Pharaoh listened to Moses' speech with boredom, almost mockingly, and he imagined him as a madman who dared to betray his lofty position. Then Pharaoh asked Moses what he wanted. Moses replied that he wanted to send the children of Israel with him.

Pharaoh was amazed when he saw Moses confronting him with this great suit, and making this great request to him. Pharaoh's last covenant with Moses was that they raised him in his palace after they picked up his ark. He fled after killing the Copt whom he found fighting with the Israeli. How great is the distance between the end of Pharaoh’s reign with Moses and this great lawsuit that he faces ten years later! Then Pharaoh began to remind him of his past. He reminds him of his upbringing. Is this the reward for the upbringing and dignity you received with us as a newborn? To come now to violate our religion, rebel against the king in whose palace you were raised, and call for a god other than him?!

He reminds him of the killing of the Copt in exaggeration and embodiment. He does not talk about it in clear terms, but rather says (and you did what you did) your hideous and hideous act (and you are of the disbelievers) in the Lord of the Worlds, which you say today, for at that time you were not talking about the Lord of the Worlds! You did not say anything about this lawsuit that you are claiming today; And you did not inform us of the beginnings of this great matter?!

Pharaoh thought that he had responded to Moses with a response that he would not have an answer for. However, God responded to Moses’ supplication before, and his tongue went out: (He said, “Then I did it while I was among those who went astray.”) I did that action while I was still ignorant, driven by the fanaticism of my people, not the drive of the belief that I know today because of the wisdom my Lord gave me. (So ​​I fled from you when I feared you) for myself. So God distributed good to me and granted me wisdom (and made me one of the messengers).

Moses continues his speech to Pharaoh with the same force: (And that is a blessing that you bestowed upon me, that you worshiped the Children of Israel.) My upbringing in your house as a child was only due to your enslavement of the Children of Israel and the killing of their children, which prompted my mother to put me in the coffin and throw him into the sea, so she would pick him up and I would be raised in your house. Not in my parents' house. Is this what you wished for me, and is this your great grace?!

At this point, the Pharaoh intervened in the conversation. Pharaoh said: And what is the Lord of the worlds?
Moses said: Lord of the heavens and the earth and all that is between them, if you are certain.
Pharaoh turned to those around him and said mockingly: Aren't you listening?
Moses said, ignoring the sarcasm of the Pharaoh: Your Lord and the Lord of your forefathers.
Pharaoh said, addressing the children of Israel who came with Moses: Your messenger who was sent to you is crazy.
Moses again went beyond the accusation and ridicule of the Pharaoh and continued: Lord of the East and the West and what is between them, if you understand. We note that Pharaoh was not asking Moses about the Lord of the Worlds or the Lord of Moses and Aaron with the intention of asking innocently and knowingly. But he was mocking. Moses answered him with a comprehensive, comprehensive, and precise answer (He said, “Our Lord is the One who gave everything its creation and then guided it.”) He is the Creator. The Creator of all races and all entities. He guides her with the characteristics that he built into her nature and created that guide her to the means of living. It's directed at her anyway. He is holding her by the corner in every case. He is the One who knows it and witnesses it in all circumstances.

This wonderful and brief statement did not affect Pharaoh. And here he is asking: (What is the matter with the first centuries?) Why did you worship this Lord of yours?

Pharaoh continued his arrogance and mockery. Moses responded by asking him that the first centuries that did not worship God, and those who worshiped Him together, will not be left without accountability and punishment. Everything is known to God Almighty. These are the first centuries (their knowledge is with my Lord in a Book). God recorded what they did in a book. (My Lord does not go astray.) That is, nothing is missed. (And he does not forget.) That is, nothing is missed. To reassure the Pharaoh regarding the first and last centuries and what is in between. God knows everything and records what they have done and does not waste any of their rewards.

Then Moses drew Pharaoh's attention to God's signs in the universe. He took him around with the movement of the wind, rain, and plants and brought him again to the earth, and there he made him understand that God created man from the earth, and He would return him to it with death, and take him out of it with resurrection. Indeed, there is resurrection then. Every human being will stand before God Almighty on the Day of Resurrection. No one is excluded. All of God's servants and creation will stand before Him on the Day of Resurrection. Including the Pharaoh. With this, Moses came as a bringer of good tidings and a warning.

Pharaoh did not like this portent, and the dialogue between him and Moses escalated. Tyranny fears nothing as much as it fears the awakening of peoples and the awakening of hearts. He does not hate anyone as he hates those who call for awareness and vigilance. He does not take revenge on anyone as he takes revenge on those who shake unconscious consciences. Therefore, Pharaoh attacked Moses and revolted, and ended the dialogue with him with an explicit threat. This is the weapon of tyrants when they lack Hajj, proof, and logic: (He said, “If you take a god other than Me, I will surely make you among those in prison.”)

However, Moses - peace be upon him - did not lose his composure. How could he lose it when he is the Messenger of God, and God is with him and his brother? Persuasion began with a new method, which is to show the miracle (he said, “Have I brought to you something clear?”) He challenges Pharaoh and embarrasses him in front of his people. If Pharaoh refused to listen, it would appear clear that he was afraid of Moses’ argument (he said, “Then bring him if you are of the truthful ones”).

Moses threw his staff into the great hall of the palace. The stick had barely touched the ground before it turned into a huge, fast-moving snake. Then he put his hand into his pocket and took it out, and it was white like the moon.

Wizards Challenge:

The second round begins between truth and falsehood. Where Pharaoh consulted with the people around him about what should be done. The people have an interest in keeping things as they are, as they are close to Pharaoh and have influence and authority. They advised him to respond to Moses' magic with a similar magic, and gather the magicians to challenge Moses and his brother.

Determine the meeqat, which is the day of adornment. The movement began to prepare the masses and motivate them, so they called on them to gather and not miss the appointment, to watch the victory of the magicians and their victory over the Israeli Moses! Crowds always gather for such things.

As for the magicians, they went to Pharaoh to be assured of the reward and reward if they defeated Moses. They are a paid group that exerts their skills in exchange for the reward they expect. It has no connection to a belief, no connection to a cause, and nothing but reward and interest. They are the ones who deserve to be rewarded for their effort, their play, and their skill in deception. And here is Pharaoh promising them more than reward. He promises them to be close to him. He claims to be king and god!

And in the battlefield. The people gathered, and Pharaoh looked on. Moses and his brother Aaron, peace be upon them, attended, and the magicians attended with all the games and tricks they had mastered in their hands, all confident of their victory in this challenge. So they began to give Moses a choice: (Either you throw, or we will be the first to throw.) Moses’ confidence - peace be upon him - was evident on the other side and his underestimation of the challenge (Rather, they threw). So the magicians threw their sticks and ropes with the pride of Pharaoh (So they threw their ropes). And they disobeyed them and said, “By the might of Pharaoh, indeed, we are the victors.”

The magicians threw their sticks and ropes, and suddenly the place was filled with snakes (they bewitched the eyes of the people, terrified them, and brought great magic). It is sufficient for us that the Holy Qur’an declares that it is great magic (and they brought great magic), so that we may realize what magic it was. It suffices for us to know that they (bewitched people's eyes) and aroused fear in their hearts (and terrified them) so that we can imagine what kind of magic it was. Moses, peace be upon him, looked at the magicians’ ropes and sticks and felt fear.

At this moment, his Lord reminds him that he has the greatest power. He is the highest. He has the truth, but they have falsehood. With him the doctrine and with them the craft. With him is the belief in the sincerity of what pushed him to where he is, and with them is the reward for the match and the gains of life. Moses is connected to greater power and the magicians serve a mortal human being, no matter how powerful a tyrant he may be.

Do not be afraid (and throw what is in your right hand) and you will defeat them, for it is magic contrived and worked by a magician. The magician does not succeed wherever he goes and which way he takes, because he relies on imagination, illusion, and deception, and does not depend on an established and lasting truth.

Moses was reassured, raised his staff and threw it. Moses' staff had barely touched the ground when the greatest miracle occurred. The magnitude of the miracle transformed the feelings and consciences of the magicians, who came to the match while they were the most eager to win in order to obtain the reward. Their ingenuity reached such an extent that Moses felt afraid of their work. Their feelings changed to the point that words were not enough for them to express: (Then the magicians fell prostrate, saying, “We believe in the Lord of Aaron and Moses.”)

It is the act of truth in pronouns. The light of truth is in the feelings, and the touch of truth is in hearts that are prepared to receive truth, light, and certainty. Magicians are the people who know the truth about their art and how far it can reach. They are the most knowledgeable people about what Moses brought. They know better whether this was the work of humans or a magician, or whether it is an ability that exceeds the ability of humans and magic. The scholar in his art is the person most willing to accept the truth when it is revealed to him, because he is closer to realizing this truth than those who know nothing about this art except the husks. Hence, the magicians turned from blatant challenge to absolute submission, which they prove within themselves with certainty.

This surprise shook the throne from under him. The surprise of the magicians - who are temple priests - surrendering to the Lord of the Worlds. Lord of Moses and Aaron. After they were gathered to nullify the call of Moses and Aaron to the Lord of the Worlds! Because the throne and power are the most important things in the lives of tyrants, they are ready to commit any crime in order to preserve them.

Pharaoh asked in amazement, “You believed in him before he gave you permission,” as if they had to ask his permission to return to the truth. But he is an arrogant and arrogant tyrant whose eyes are blinded by the Sultan from the truth. He increases his tyranny and says (Indeed, this is a plan that you plotted in the city to expel its people from it). If it prevailed over you on this day of yours, it was only based on your consultation and your consent for that, and he and everyone who has reason knows that this is what he said is one of the nullification of falsehood. The tyrant keeps threatening (You will know) and threatening (I will cut off your hands and your feet on opposite sides, then I will crucify you all together), but when the human soul becomes certain of the truth of faith, it rises above the power of the earth and underestimates the might of the tyrants. In which faith triumphs over life, and chooses permanent immortality over mortal life. (They say, “Indeed, we are returning to our Lord.”) It is the faith that does not waver or submit.

The magicians announce the reality of the battle (And it does not take vengeance on us unless we believe in the signs of our Lord when they have come to us). They do not ask for pardon and pardon from their enemy, but rather they ask for steadfastness and patience from their Lord (Our Lord, pour upon us patience and cause us to die. Muslims). Tyranny stands helpless in the face of this awareness and this reassurance. We are unable to return these believers to the path of falsehood again. He carries out his threat and crucifies them on the trunks of palm trees.

Conspiracy against Moses and those who believed with him:

A new round begins between truth and falsehood. Here they were the high-ranking Egyptian people, conspiring and inciting Pharaoh, agitating him against Moses and those who believed with him, and frightening him of the consequences of being negligent with them. They see the call to God’s lordship and unity as spreading corruption on earth. As it would invalidate the legitimacy of Pharaoh’s rule and his entire system. Pharaoh derived his power from their false religion, as Pharaoh was the son of the gods. If Moses and those with him worshiped God, Lord of the Worlds, Pharaoh would not have any power over them. These words provoked Pharaoh and made him feel the real danger to his entire regime. He thought of his usual brutality and decided (He said, “We will kill their sons and spare their women, and we are subjugated over them.”)

This brutal abuse was not new to the children of Israel. This ruling was implemented on them during the birth of Moses, peace be upon him. So Moses - peace be upon him - began to advise his people to endure strife, be patient in the face of calamity, and seek God’s help over it. And the earth belongs to God, and He grants it to whomever He wishes of His servants. The outcome is for the one who fears God and does not fear anyone but Him (Moses said to his people, “Seek help from God and be patient. Indeed, the earth belongs to God. He makes it inheritable to whomever He wishes of His servants, and the outcome is for the righteous.”)

However, his people began to complain about the torment that befell them (they said, “We were harmed before you came to us and after you came to us”). These are words with a shadow! And it reveals what lies behind it! We were harmed before your coming, and nothing has changed with your coming. This harm lasted until it seemed to have no end! The Holy Prophet continued his approach. He reminds them of God, places their hope in Him, and gives them hope in the destruction of their enemy. And their succession in the land. With a warning against the temptation of succession, God’s appointment of them as successors is a test for them, as it is a test for succession: (He said, “Perhaps your Lord will destroy your enemy and appoint you as your successor in the land and see how you do.”)

The Holy Qur’an takes us to another chapter of the story of Moses, peace be upon him. Another scene of the confrontation between truth and falsehood. Where Lama tells the story of Pharaoh consulting with the public about killing Moses. (And Pharaoh said, “Let me kill Moses and let him call on his Lord. I fear that he will change your religion or that corruption will appear on earth.”) As for Moses, peace be upon him, he took refuge in the solid corner and the fortified fortress, and took refuge. The protector of those who seek protection, and the protector of those who seek refuge (And Moses said, “Indeed, I seek refuge in my Lord and your Lord from every arrogant person who does not believe in the Day of Judgment).

The position of the believing man towards the family of Pharaoh:

Pharaoh's idea would have almost been approved had it not been for a man from Pharaoh's family. A man of great statesmen. The Qur’an does not mention his name, because his name does not matter. He also did not mention his description because his description does not mean anything. Rather, the Qur’an mentioned that he was a man of faith. Remind him of the attribute after which no other attribute has any value.

This man of faith spoke, and he was (hiding his faith). He spoke at the meeting in which the idea of ​​killing Moses was raised and proved the futility and superficiality of the idea. He said that Moses did not say more than that God is his Lord, and after that he came with clear evidence that he was a messenger, and there are two possibilities without a third: that Moses was a liar, or that he was telling the truth, and if he was a liar (then his lie is on him), and he did not say or do anything that would necessitate his killing. If he is honest and we kill him, what is the guarantee that we will be saved from the torment that he promises us?

The believer who concealed his faith spoke and said to his people: Today we are in positions of rule and power. Who will protect us from God's punishment when it comes? Who will save us from his punishment if it comes? Our extravagance and lying may waste us.

His words seemed convincing. He is a man who is not accused of loyalty to Pharaoh. He is not a follower of Moses. It is assumed that he speaks out of concern for the throne of the Pharaoh. Nothing brings down thrones like lying, extravagance, and killing innocent people.

From this place, the words of the believing man derived their strength. For Pharaoh, his ministers, and his men. Although Pharaoh found his idea of ​​killing Moses a sacrifice on the table. Despite the believer's intimidation of Pharaoh. Despite this, the Pharaoh said his historical word that became an example after him for all tyrants: (Pharaoh said, “I show you only what I see, and I guide you only to the right path.”)

This is what tyrants always say when they confront their people: “I show you only what I see.” This is our personal opinion, and it is an opinion that will guide you to guidance. Every other opinion is wrong. We must stand against it and eradicate it.

The discussion did not stop there. Pharaoh said his word, but it did not convince the believing man. The believing man spoke again and brought them evidence from history, sufficient evidence of the truthfulness of Moses. He warned them not to harm him. They were preceded by nations that disbelieved in their messengers, so God destroyed them: the people of Noah, the people of Ad, the people of Thamud.

Then he reminded them of the history of Egypt itself. He reminded them of Joseph, peace be upon him, when he came with clear proofs, but the people doubted him and then believed in him after salvation had almost eluded them. What is strange about God sending messengers? Ancient history should be considered. When the believing few became believers, they triumphed over the unbelieving many. And God Almighty crushed the unbelievers. He drowned them with a flood, and stunned them with a scream. Or the earth will swallow them up. So what are we waiting for? How do we know that our standing behind the Pharaoh will not cause us to lose and destroy us all?

The believer's speech contained many frightening warnings. It seems that he convinced those present that the idea of ​​killing Moses was an idea with unsafe consequences. Therefore, there is no need for it.

However, the tyrant Pharaoh once again tried to negotiate and camouflage, so as not to openly face the truth, and not acknowledge the call of oneness that shook his throne. It is far from possible that this was Pharaoh’s understanding and understanding. So he asked for a great building to be built for him, so he could climb onto it to see the God of Moses whom he claimed to be. Far from being serious about searching for the God of Moses in this naive, materialistic manner. The Pharaohs of Egypt had reached a level of culture that banished this perception. But it is recklessness and sarcasm on the one hand. And pretending to be fair and assertive on the other hand.

After this recklessness and this insistence, the man of faith gave his final resounding and frank speech: And he who believed said, “O my people, follow me. I will guide you to the path of right guidance.” (38) “O my people, this life of this world is only an enjoyment, and the Hereafter is an abode.” Al-Qarar (39) Whoever does an evil deed will not be rewarded except the like of it, and whoever does righteousness, whether male or female, and is a believer - those will enter Paradise. They will be provided therein without reckoning. (40) O my people, what is the matter with me? I call you to salvation and you call me to Hell. (41) You call me to disbelieve in God, and Enter into it that of which I have no knowledge, and I invite you to the Mighty, the Forgiving (42) It is no offense that whatever you invite me to, he has no invitation in this world nor In the Hereafter, we will return to God, and the transgressors are the inmates of the Fire. (43) So you will remember what I say to you, and I entrust my matter to God. All-Seeing of His servants (44) (Ghafir)

The man of faith ended his speech with these courageous words. Then he left. He left and the people sitting turned from Moses to him. They began to plot against the believing man. They started talking about what came out of it. Then the providence of God Almighty intervened (so God protected him from the evils of what they plotted, and an evil torment befell Pharaoh’s family) and saved him from Pharaoh and his soldiers.

May God test the people of Egypt:

As for the situation in Egypt during that period. Pharaoh continued his threat, killing the men and sparing the women. Moses and his people continued to endure the torment, hoping for God’s relief, and being patient with the test. Pharaoh remained in his shadow and his defiance. Then the power of God Almighty intervened, and God Almighty wanted to put pressure on Pharaoh’s family. As a test and intimidation for them, and to divert them from plotting against Moses and those who believed with him, and to prove Moses’ prophecy and truthfulness at the same time. Thus, years of drought were imposed on the Egyptians. The land became barren, the Nile became scarce, the fruits decreased, the people became hungry, and the drought increased. But the family of Pharaoh did not realize the relationship between their disbelief and immorality and their transgression and oppression of the servants of God. So they started explaining the reasons. When a good thing happens to them, they say that it is their good fortune and that they deserve it. And if an evil befalls them, they say that it is a bad omen for Moses and those with him, and that it is from under their heads!

Pride led them to sin, and they believed that Moses' magic was responsible for the drought that befell them. It depicted their foolishness that this barrenness that afflicted their land was a sign that Moses brought to enchant them, and it was a sign that they would not believe in no matter what happened.

So God strengthened them, so that they might return to God and release the children of Israel and send them with him. So He sent upon them a flood, locusts, lice, frogs, and blood. The Qur’an does not mention whether it was one sentence, or one after the other. Some narratives mention that they came successively, one after another. However, what is important is that Pharaoh’s family asked Moses to pray to his Lord to save them from this affliction. They promised him every time to send the Children of Israel if he saved them and lifted this affliction from them. Children of Israel).

Moses - peace be upon him - was praying to God to remove the torment from them. As soon as the affliction is revealed, they break their covenant and return to what they were in. (But when We removed from them the punishment for a term, they had fulfilled it. When they broke it.)

The Egyptians were not converted, nor did they fulfill their covenants, on the contrary. Pharaoh went out to his people and declared that he was a god. Does he not have the king of Egypt, and these rivers flow beneath him? I declare that Moses is a lying magician. A poor man does not wear a single gold bracelet.

The Holy Qur’an expresses the matter of Pharaoh and his people: (But he belittled his people, so they obeyed him). Underestimate their minds. And he underestimated their freedom. And underestimate their future. And he underestimated their humanity. So they obeyed him. Isn't this a strange obedience? The strangeness disappears when we know that they were immoral people. Immorality distracts a person from paying attention to his future, interests, and affairs, and leads him to destruction. This is what happened to Pharaoh's people.

The Exodus of the Children of Israel from Egypt:

It seemed clear that Pharaoh would not trust Moses. He will not stop torturing the children of Israel, and he will not stop belittling his people. There Moses and Aaron called against Pharaoh.

And Moses said, “Our Lord, you have come to Pharaoh and filled him with adornments and wealth in the life of this world. Our Lord, so that they may go astray from Your path. Our Lord, wipe out their wealth.” And harden their hearts, so they will not believe until they see the painful punishment. (88) He said, “Your supplication has been answered, so be steadfast, and do not follow the path of those who do not They know (89) (Yunus)

No group of his people believed with Moses. So the matter ended, and Moses was inspired to leave Egypt with the children of Israel. Their departure should take place at night, after planning and organizing the departure. He informed him that Pharaoh would follow them with his soldiers. He ordered his people to go to the sea coast (which is usually where the Gulf of Suez meets the Lakes region).

The news reached Pharaoh that Moses had accompanied his people and left. So he sent his orders to the cities of the kingdom to mobilize a great army. To overtake Moses and his people, and spoil their plan. Pharaoh announced general mobilization. This would create an image in people’s minds that Moses and his people posed a threat to Pharaoh and his kingdom. How could he be the god of someone who fears a small group that worships another god?! Therefore, it was necessary to trivialize the matter by belittling the status and size of Moses’ people (they are a small group), but we pursue them because they have angered us, and in any case, we are cautious and prepared to take control of matters.

Moses stood in front of the sea. The Pharaoh's army seemed to be approaching, and its flags appeared. Moses' people were filled with terror. The situation was critical and dangerous. The sea is in front of them and the enemy is behind them. They do not have ships or tools to cross the sea, and they do not have a single opportunity to fight. They are a group of women, children and unarmed men. Pharaoh will slaughter all of them.

Some voices from Moses' people shouted: Pharaoh will overtake us.
Moses said: (No, indeed my Lord is with me. He will guide me.)

Moses did not know what his salvation would be like, but his heart was full of trust in his Lord, certainty of His help, and certainty of salvation, for God is the one who guides and takes care of him. And at the last moment, the revelation comes from God (So We revealed to Moses, “Strike the sea with your staff”), so he struck it, and the miracle occurred (and it split, and each part was like a great mountain) and he achieved the impossible according to people’s logic, but if God wanted something, He said to it, “Be.” So it is.

And Pharaoh reached the sea. Watch this miracle. In the sea he saw a dry road split in two. So he ordered his army to advance. When Moses finished crossing the sea. God inspired Moses to leave the sea as it is (and leave the sea alone. Indeed, they are a drowned host). God Almighty had wanted to drown the Pharaoh. As soon as Pharaoh and his soldiers were in the middle of the sea, God issued his command, and the waves crashed on Pharaoh and his army. Pharaoh and his army drowned. Stubbornness sank and faith in God survived.

When Pharaoh witnessed drowning, and he was no longer able to survive (he said, “I believe that there is no god but the one in whom the children of Israel believe, and I am of the Muslims”), all false masks fell from him, and diminished, so he was not content with declaring his faith, but also surrendering. (And I am one of the Muslims) But to no avail, now is not the time to choose. After disobedience and arrogance preceded (now you have disobeyed before and were among the corruptors).

The time of repentance appointed for you has expired and you have perished. It's over and there's no escape for you. Only your body will survive. The fish will not eat it, and the current will carry it away from people. Rather, your body will survive to be a sign for those behind you.

Today We will save you with your body so that you may be a sign for those behind you. Indeed, many of the people are heedless of Our signs. (92) (Yunus)

The curtain came down on the tyranny of the Pharaoh. The waves washed his body onto the shore. after that. The curtain came down completely for the Egyptians. They set out to follow in the footsteps of Moses and his people and follow in their footsteps. This was their last exit. It was a release for them from all the gardens, springs, and treasures they were in. They did not return to this bliss after that! The Holy Qur’an does not tell us about what the remaining Egyptians did in Egypt after the fall of the Pharaoh’s regime and its drowning along with his army. He does not tell us about their reactions after God destroyed what Pharaoh and his people were doing and what they were building. The Qur’anic context is silent about them. It completely excludes them from history and events.

The humiliated psychology of the children of Israel:

The Pharaoh of Egypt has died. He drowned before the eyes of the Egyptians and the children of Israel. Despite his death, his impact remained in the souls of the Egyptians and the children of Israel. It is difficult for the long years of oppression and intense humiliation to pass unnoticed by people. Pharaoh accustomed the children of Israel to humiliation before anyone other than God. He defeated their souls and corrupted their nature, so they tortured Moses severely due to stubbornness and ignorance.

The miracle of parting the sea was still fresh in their minds when they passed by people who worshiped idols. Instead of showing their dissatisfaction with this injustice to the mind, they thank God for guiding them to faith. Instead, they turned to Moses and asked him to make them a god whom these people could worship. They became jealous at the sight of idols, desired similar ones, and nostalgia returned to them for the ancient days of polytheism that they had lived under Pharaoh. Moses called them to their ignorance, and explained to them that the actions of these people were false, and that God preferred the children of Israel over the worlds, so how could he deny this preference and make them an idol to worship instead of God? Then he reminded them of Pharaoh and his torment of them, and how God saved them from him, so how after that do they associate with God that which neither harms nor benefits?

Moses’ appointment to meet his Lord:

The first stage of the mission of Moses, peace be upon him, was completed, which was to rid the children of Israel from a life of humiliation and torture at the hands of Pharaoh and his soldiers. And take them to the Holy Land. But the people were not ready for the great mission, the mission of caliphate on earth according to the religion of God. The first test was the biggest proof of this. As soon as they saw people worshiping an idol, the belief of monotheism was shaken in their souls, and they asked Moses to make them an idol to worship. A detailed message was necessary to educate this nation and prepare it for what they were about to face. For the sake of this message, God promised His servant Moses to meet him. This dating was a preparation for Moses’ soul to prepare for the great and formidable situation. So he appointed his brother Aaron, peace be upon him, as his successor in his people.

The preparation period was thirty nights, to which ten were added, making its number equal to forty nights. In it, Moses prepares himself for the promised meeting. He isolates himself from the concerns of the earth; His soul is cleared and his resolve is strengthened. Ibn Katheer mentions in his interpretation of the matter of these nights: “Then God Almighty mentioned that He promised Moses thirty nights. The commentators said: So Moses - peace be upon him - fasted and folded them. When the appointed time was complete, he rested himself with the bark of a tree, so God Almighty commanded him to complete the ten forty.”

By fasting - for forty nights - Moses was getting closer to his Lord. By God speaking to Moses, his love for his Lord increased even more. So Moses asked to see God. We do not know what feelings were surging in the heart of Moses, peace and blessings be upon him, when he asked his Lord for the vision. Many times human love pushes people to ask for the impossible. What about divine love, which is the origin of love? The depth of Moses' feeling for his Lord, his love for his Creator, and his enthusiasm still characterize his personality. All of this prompted him to ask God for a vision.

And the response of the Truth, the Almighty, came to him: He said, “You will not see me.”

If God, Blessed and Most High, had said it and not added anything to it, this would have been just on His part, Glory be to Him. However, the situation here is one of divine love on the part of Moses. An impulsive attitude justified by love and that is why the mercy of God Almighty was recognized by Moses. I understand him that he will not see him, because none of creation can withstand the light of God. He ordered him to look at the mountain, and if he stayed in place, he would see him.

God Almighty said: (But look at the mountain, and if it remains in its place, you will see Me. And when his Lord manifested Himself to the mountain, He caused it to be flattened, and Moses fell down stunned.)

No one can withstand the light of God. So he destroyed the mountain and became leveled in the ground. Musa fell unconscious, losing consciousness. When he regained consciousness, he said, Glory be to You, You are exalted above what eyes see and comprehend. I repent to you that I went beyond the scope of your question! I am the first to believe in you and your greatness.

Then the mercy of his Lord will heal him again. Moses - peace be upon him - receives the good news. Good news of selection. With guidance to him to send the message to his people after salvation. God Almighty said: (He said, O Moses, I have chosen you above the people with My messages and with My words, so take what I have given you and be among those who are thankful.)

Many commentators have commented on what God Almighty said to Moses: (Indeed, I have chosen you over the people with My messages and with My words). Comparisons were made between him and other prophets. It was said that this selection was specific to his era alone, and did not apply to the era that preceded it due to the presence of Abraham in it, and Abraham was better than Moses. Also, this selection does not apply to the era that comes after it, due to the presence of Muhammad bin Abdullah in it, and he is better than them.

We would like to stay away from this whole debate. No, because we believe that all prophets are equal. So, God Almighty tells us that He favored some prophets over others, and raised the ranks of some over others. However, this preference should be a forbidden area for us, and let us stand in a position of faith in all the prophets and not go beyond it. Let us pay respect to them both. Sinners should not delve into the degrees of infallible people chosen by God. It is not polite for us to differentiate between the prophets. The first is to believe in them all.

Then God Almighty explains the content of the message (And We wrote for him on the tablets of everything an exhortation and a detail of everything, so take it with strength and command your people to take With the best of them, I will show you the abode of the transgressors.) It contains everything related to the subject of the message and its purpose, from the explanation of God and His law, and the directions required to reform the condition of this nation and the nature of It has been corrupted by humiliation and long term!

Calf worship:

Moses' time with his Lord Almighty ended. He returned angry and sad to his people. God told him that his people had gone astray after him. And a man from the children of Israel called the Samaritan was the one who led them astray. Moses descended from the mountaintop carrying the tablets of the Torah, his heart boiling with anger and regret. We can imagine Moses' excitement and revolt as he stepped forward towards his people.

Moses had hardly left his people for the appointed time of his Lord. Until the Samaritan temptation occurred. The details of this strife are that when the Children of Israel left Egypt, they took with them a lot of Egyptian jewelry and gold, which the women of the Children of Israel had borrowed to adorn themselves with, and when they were ordered to leave, they carried it with them. Then they threw it away because it was forbidden. So the Samaritan took it and made a statue of a calf out of it. The Samaritan was apparently a professional sculptor or former goldsmith, so he made the calf hollow from the inside, and placed it in the direction of the wind, so that air entered through its back hole and exited through its nostrils, making a sound similar to the bellowing of real calves. It is said that the secret of this bellowing is that the Samaritan had taken a handful of dust on which Gabriel - peace be upon him - walked when he descended to earth in the miracle of parting the sea. That is, the Samaritan saw what they did not see, so he took a handful of the traces of the Messenger - Gabriel, peace be upon him - and placed it with gold while making a calf from it. Gabriel would not walk on anything without life coming to him. When the Samaritan added dirt to gold, then made a calf from it, the calf came out like real calves. This is the story that the Samaritan told Moses, peace be upon him.

After that, the Samaritan went out against the children of Israel for what he had done.

They asked him: What is this, Samaritan?
He said: This is your God and the God of Moses!
They said: But Moses went to the appointment of his God.
The Samaritan said: Moses forgot. He went to meet his Lord there, while his Lord is here.

A wave of wind blew, and gold entered the calf's anus and pottery came out of the calf's mouth. The children of Israel worshiped this calf. Perhaps the reader will be astonished at this fascination. How can people's minds be underestimated to this degree?! Tremendous miracles happened to them. How can they turn to idolatry in an instant? This astonishment disappears if we look at the psychology of the people who worshiped the calf. They were raised in Egypt, in the days when Egypt worshiped idols and sanctified it while it sanctified the Apis calf, and they were raised on humiliation and slavery, so their souls changed, and berries became their nature, and God’s miracles passed through them and they encountered souls with lost hope. There was nothing more that anyone could do for them. God's words did not return them to the truth, nor did the physical miracles convince them of the truth of the words. Deep down, they remained idolaters. They were pagans like their ancient Egyptian masters. For this reason, they turned to worshiping the calf.

One day, Aaron, peace and blessings be upon him, was surprised that the children of Israel were worshiping a golden calf. They were divided into two parts: The believing minority realized that this was nonsense. The infidel majority submitted to their longing to worship idols. Aaron stood among his people and began to preach to them. He said to them: You have been tempted by him. This is a temptation. The Samaritan took advantage of your ignorance and temptation with his haste. This is not your Lord, nor the Lord of Moses (And indeed your Lord is the Most Gracious, so follow me and obey my command).

The calf worshipers rejected Aaron's sermon. But Aaron - peace be upon him - returned to preaching to them and reminding them of the miracles by which God saved them, and His honor and care for them, so they turned a deaf ear and rejected his words, weakened him and almost killed him, and they ended the discussion of the topic by postponing it until the return of Moses. It was clear that Aaron was more gentle than Moses. He was not feared by the people for his gentleness and compassion. Aaron feared that he would resort to force and destroy their idol that they worshiped, thus causing strife among the people. Aaron preferred to postpone the matter until Moses arrived.

He knew that Moses, with his strong personality, could put an end to this strife. The people continued dancing around the calf.

Moses descended back to his people and heard the people's shouting and the excitement of them dancing around the calf. The people stopped when Moses appeared and there was silence. Moses shouted, saying: “Wretched is it that you succeeded me after me.”

Moses turned to Aaron and threw the Torah tablets from his hand onto the ground. The hurricane of anger inside Musa was completely controlled by him. Moses extended his hands and grabbed Aaron by the hair of his head and the hair of his beard and pulled him towards him while he was trembling. Musa said:

O Aaron, what prevented you from following me when you saw them going astray? (92) Did you disobey My command? (93) (Taha)

Moses wonders whether Aaron disobeyed his command. How did you remain silent about this strife? How did he agree to stay with them and not leave them and disown them? How did he remain silent about their resistance in the first place? The one who is silent about the mistake participates in it in some way. The silence deepened after Musa's angry sentence. Aaron spoke to Moses. He asked him to leave his head and beard. By right of belonging to one mother. It reminds him of his mother and does not remind him of his father, so that this is more likely to arouse feelings of compassion in himself.

I understand him that there is no disobedience to him. He is not satisfied with the position of the calf worshipers. Rather, he was afraid that he would leave them and go away, so Moses asked him how he did not remain among them when Moses left him in charge of them, and he feared that if he resisted them violently, he would provoke a fight among them, so Moses asked him how he separated them and did not wait for his return.

Aaron gently and softly informed his brother Moses that the people considered him weak, and almost killed him when he resisted them. He asked him to leave his head and beard so that the enemies would not gloat over him and the people would not disdain him even more than they disdained him. I made him understand that he was not as unjust as they were when he remained silent about their injustice.

Moses realized that he had wronged Aaron in his anger, which was ignited by his jealousy of God Almighty and his desire for the truth. I realize that Aaron acted as best as he could in the circumstances. He left his head and beard and asked God for forgiveness for him and his brother. Moses turned to his people and asked in a voice still turbulent with anger: “O my people, did your Lord not promise you a good promise? Did He invalidate the covenant for you, or did you want the wrath of your Lord to descend upon you? So you broke my promise. He scolds them, scolds them, and quickly points out the stupidity of what they did. Moses returned, saying with extreme anger: (Indeed, those who adopted the calf will incur wrath from their Lord and humiliation in the life of this world. And thus do We reward the inventors.)

The mountains had barely swallowed the echoes of the angry voice before the people bowed their heads and realized their mistake. Their slander was clear against the truth brought by Moses. After everything God Almighty did for them, they resorted to worshiping idols?! Did Moses disappear for forty days and then return to find them worshiping a golden calf? Is this the behavior of a people to whom God has entrusted the faithfulness of monotheism on earth?

Moses turned to the Samaritan after his short conversation with Aaron. Aaron proved to him his innocence as the one responsible for his people during his absence. Just as the people remained silent and bowed their heads in the face of Moses’ revolution, only the first person responsible for the sedition remained. Only the Samaritan remained.

Moses spoke to the Samaritan and his anger had not subsided yet: He said, “What is wrong with you, Samaritan?”
He asks him about his story, and wants to know from him what made him do what he did. Al-Samari said: I saw what they did not see.
I saw Gabriel riding his horse, and she would not put her foot on anything until it came to life. So I took a handful of the Messenger’s trace.
I took a handful of the dirt that Gabriel walked on and threw it on the gold. So I rejected her, and likewise she made peace with me.
This is what I led myself to.

Moses, peace be upon him, did not discuss the Samaritan in his claim. Rather, the judgment of truth was thrown in his face. It is not important that the Samaritan saw Gabriel, peace be upon him, and caught a glimpse of him. It is not important whether the calf's mooing was because of this dirt on which Gabriel's horse walked, or whether the mooing was because of a hole made by the Samaritan to make the calf moo. What is important in the whole matter is the Samaritan’s crime, his sedition of the people of Moses, and his exploitation of the people’s hidden admiration for their Egyptian masters, and their imitation of them in worshiping idols. This is the crime for which Moses, peace be upon him, was judged: (He said, “Go, for in life you have the right to say, ‘No touching,’ and you have a promise which you will not break. And look to your God, whom you have kept. We will burn it, then we will blow it up. He is in the river, blowing up.)

Moses condemned the Samaritan to loneliness in this world. Some commentators say: Moses called on the Samaritan not to touch anyone, as a punishment for touching him unless he should have touched him.

We believe that the matter is much more dangerous than this quick glance. By his temptation, the Samaritan wanted to lead the children of Israel astray, gather them around his pagan calf, and dominate them. His punishment was equal to his crime. He was sentenced to ostracism and loneliness. Did the Samaritan suffer from a hideous skin disease that made people feel uncomfortable touching him or even getting close to him? Did the rejection come to him from outside his body? We do not know what was the matter of the manner in which the Samaritan was united and rejected by society. All we know is that Moses inflicted a terrible punishment on him, which was easier than killing him. The Samaritan lived as a despised outcast, not touching anything, touching anyone, and not being approached by any creature. This is his punishment in this world, and on the Day of Resurrection he will have a second punishment, which the context obscures so that its shadows appear in the soul more dangerous and terrifying.

After finishing the Samaritan, Moses got up to the golden calf and threw it into the fire. He not only melted him down before the eyes of the astonished people, but also blew him up in the sea. The worshiped god was transformed before the eyes of those fascinated by him into ashes flying into the sea. Moses' voice rose: (Indeed, your God is Allah; there is no god but Him. He encompasses all things in knowledge.) This is your God, and not that idol that has no benefit or harm for itself.

After Moses blew up the idol and got rid of the original culprit, he turned to his people and ruled on the whole case. He made them understand that they had wronged themselves and left the calf worshipers with only one room to repent. This scope was for the obedient Bani Isra’i to kill those who disobeyed.

God Almighty said:

And when Moses said to his people, “O my people, you have wronged yourselves by adopting the calf, so repent to your Creator, and kill yourselves.” That is what Moses said to his people. Better for you is with your Creator, so He has turned to you. Indeed, He is the Forgiving, the Merciful. (54) (Al-Baqarah)

The punishment that Moses imposed on the calf worshipers was severe, and consistent with the original crime. Worshiping idols is a waste of the life and awakening of the mind, which is the awakening that distinguishes man from other animals and inanimate objects. In light of this loss of the awakening of the mind, the punishment comes as the loss of the life of the body itself. After the mind, man has no life by which he can be distinguished. Depending on the type of crime came the punishment. It was harsh, then God Almighty had mercy and repented. Indeed, He is the Most Merciful.

finally. Moses' anger remained silent. Consider the expression of the Holy Qur’an, which depicts anger in the form of a being guiding Moses’ actions, starting with him throwing the tablets of the Torah, and pulling his brother’s beard and head. It ended with the calf being blown up in the sea, and the death sentence for those who took it as usury. Finally, Moses' anger calmed down. His anger in God is removed, and that is the highest type of anger and most worthy of respect and reverence. Moses turned to his original mission when his anger passed, and he remembered that he had thrown the Torah tablets. Moses returned to take the tablets and resume his call to God.

Raising the mountain above the heads of the children of Israel:

Moses returned to his calm, resumed his struggle in God, and read the tablets of the Torah to his people. He initially ordered them to adhere to its provisions with strength and determination. It is surprising that his people bargained with him for the truth. They said: Deploy the tablets for us, and if their commands and prohibitions are easy, we will accept them. Moses said: Rather, accept it for what is in it. So they reviewed it repeatedly, then God Almighty commanded His angels, and they raised the mountain over their heads until it became like a cloud above them, and it was said to them: If you do not accept it with what is in it, that mountain will fall on you, so they accepted that, and were commanded to prostrate, so they prostrated. They placed their cheeks on the ground and looked at the mountain above them in fear and horror.

Thus, the people of Moses proved that they would not submit their faces to God unless their necks were twisted by a dazzling sensory miracle that struck fear in the hearts and the feet were folded into an all-powerful prostration that drove fear to Him. Thus, people are led by the divine rod to faith. This occurs in the absence of sufficient awareness and maturity to establish rational conviction. Perhaps here we refer once again to the psychology of Moses’ people, which is primarily responsible for their lack of conviction except through sensory power and dazzling miracles. Moses' people were raised and brought up in the midst of humiliation and humiliation, in which their humanity and berries were wasted. It is no longer possible after humiliation has flourished in their souls and they have become accustomed to it. It is no longer possible for them to be led to goodness except by force. They are accustomed to being governed by the force majeure of their old masters, and their new master (which is faith) must endure the horrors to control them, and must resort to force to save them from destruction. The crime of worshiping the calf did not pass without traces.

Choosing seventy men for the appointed time of God:

Moses commanded the children of Israel to ask God for forgiveness and repent to Him. He chose seventy men from them, the best after the best, and said, “Go to God and repent to Him for what you have done, and ask Him to repent for those of your people you left behind.” Fast, purify yourself, and purify your clothes. Moses went out with these seventy chosen ones to a time specified for him by God Almighty. Moses approached the mountain. God Almighty spoke to Moses, and the seventy heard Moses speaking to his Lord.

Perhaps a miracle like this will be the last, and will be enough to carry faith into hearts for life. However, the chosen seventy were not satisfied with the miracle they heard. They only asked to see God Almighty. They said we heard and we want to see. They simply said to Moses: (O Moses, we will not believe in you until we see God clearly).

It is a tragedy that raises the most astonishment. It is a tragedy that indicates the hardness of hearts and their attachment to sensibilities and material things. The stubborn request was rewarded with a stunning punishment. They were struck by a devastating tremor that instantly stunned their souls and bodies. They died.

Moses realized what the chosen seventy had done, and he was filled with sorrow, and he stood up to pray to his Lord and implored him to pardon them and have mercy on them, and not to hold them accountable for what the foolish ones among them had done, and their request to see God, Blessed and Most High, while they were in the state of imperfect humanity and hardness of heart was nothing but great foolishness. A foolishness that can only be atoned for by death.

The Prophet may ask to see his Lord, as Moses did, and despite the fact that the request stems from the reality of great love and controlling passion, which justifies this request with its own logic, despite all of this, the request for a vision is considered an overstep of the limits, and the Prophet punishes him by being struck by shock. So what about this request coming from sinful human beings, human beings who specify a place and time for the vision, after all the miracles and signs they have encountered...? Isn't this a huge foolishness? Thus, the one who asked for the vision was stunned... and Moses stood praying to his Lord, pleading with Him and pleasing to Him. The Almighty God narrates the supplication of Moses, peace be upon him, for repentance against his people in Surah Al-A’raf:

And Moses chose seventy men from his people for Our appointed time, and when the tremor seized them, he said, “My Lord, if You wished, You could have destroyed them before, and I could have destroyed us.” Because the foolish among us have done. It is nothing but your temptation with which you lead astray whomever you wish and guide whomever you wish. You are our guardian, so forgive us and have mercy on us, and you are the best of forgivers. (155) And decree for us good in this world and in the Hereafter. We have been guided to you. He said, “My punishment inflicts upon whomever I will, and My mercy encompasses all things, so I will record it for those who fear and pay zakat, and those who are They believe in Our signs (156) Those who follow the Messenger, the unlettered Prophet, whom they find written down with them in the Torah and the Gospel. He enjoins upon them what is good. And He forbids them from evil, and makes lawful for them the good things, and prohibits for them the evil, and relieves them of their burden and the shackles. (157) (157) (Al-A'raf)

These were Moses' words to his Lord as he called upon Him and sought His pleasure. And God Almighty was pleased with him and forgave his people, so he revived them after their death, and the chosen ones, in these brilliant moments in the history of life, listened to the prophecy of the coming of Muhammad bin Abdullah, may God bless him and grant him peace. We will notice the way of linking the present and the past in the verse. God Almighty goes beyond the time of addressing the Messenger in the verses to two previous times, namely the revelation of the Torah and the revelation of the Gospel, to decide that He (the Almighty) gave good tidings to Muhammad in these two noble books. We believe that this good news came on the day Moses accompanied seventy men from his people, the elders of the Children of Israel and the best among them, to the appointed time of his Lord. On this dangerous day with its great miracles, good news was brought about the last of the prophets of God Almighty.

Ibn Katheer says in his book Stories of the Prophets, quoting Qatada:

Moses said to his Lord: O Lord, I find in the Tablets a nation that is the best nation ever brought forth for mankind. They enjoin what is right and forbid what is wrong. Lord, make them my nation.
He said: This is the nation of Ahmad.
He said: My Lord, I find in the Tablets a nation with Bibles in their chests that they read. And those before them used to read their book from view, until when they read it they did not memorize anything and did not know it. And God gave them something to memorize that He had not given to any of the nations. Lord, make them my nation.
He said: This is the nation of Ahmad.
He said: My Lord, I find in the Tablets a nation who believe in the First Book and the Last Book, and fight the misguidance of misguidance. So make them my nation.
He said: This is the nation of Ahmad.
He said: My Lord, I find in the Tablets a nation whose alms they eat in their stomachs, and they are rewarded for it.
