And before them were nations who, if one of them gave alms in charity and it was accepted from him, God would send fire upon it and it consumed it, and if it returned to him, it would be left and wild beasts and birds would eat it. And God took their charity from the rich among them to the poor. Lord, make them my nation.
He said: This is the nation of Ahmad.
He said: O Lord, I find in the Tablets a nation that if one of them intended to do a good deed and then did it, it wrote for him ten times as much, up to seven hundred times as much. Lord, make them my nation.
He said: This is the nation of Ahmad.

Descent of manna and quail:

Moses led his people in Sinai. It is a desert with no trees to protect it from the sun, and there is no food or water. God's mercy reached them, and manna and quails were poured to them and clouds shaded them. Manna is a substance that tends to taste sweet and is secreted by some fruit trees. God sent quail to them, which is a type of bird said to be (quail). When their thirst for water became intense, and Sinai was a place devoid of water, Moses struck the stone for them with his staff, and twelve springs of water gushed from it. The children of Israel were divided into 12 tribes. So God sent water to each group. Despite this honor and hospitality, sick contortions were stirred in the souls. Moses' people protested that they were tired of this food, and their souls longed for onions, garlic, beans, and lentils, and these foods were traditional Egyptian foods. Thus, the children of Israel asked their Prophet Moses to pray to God to bring these foods out of the earth for them.

Moses returned to begging them about their injustice to themselves, their nostalgia for the days of their humiliation in Egypt, and how they prided themselves on the best and most honorable food, and wanted in exchange for the lowest and worst food.

Walking towards Jerusalem:

Moses walked with his people towards the Holy House. Moses ordered his people to enter it, fight those in it, and seize it. And now their last test has come. After all the miracles, signs, and supernatural things that happened to them. It was their turn to fight - as believers - a people who worshiped idols.

Moses' people refused to enter the Holy Land. Moses told them about God's blessings upon them. How He made prophets among them, made them kings to inherit the kingdom of Pharaoh, and gave them what He had not given to any of the worlds.

His people's response to him was that they were afraid of fighting. They said: There are mighty people there, and they will not enter the Holy Land until these people leave it.

Two of the people joined Moses and Aaron. The books of the ancients say that they went out in six hundred thousand. Moses found only two men among them ready to fight. These two men began trying to convince the people to enter the land and fight. They said: Their mere entry through the door will bring them victory. But all of the children of Israel were covering themselves with cowardice and trembling deep inside.

Once again, their nature returns to them, which returned to them before that when they saw people devoting themselves to their idols. Their nature was corrupted, they were defeated from within, and they became accustomed to humiliation, so they were no longer able to fight. And if they still can, they will be impudent against the Prophet of God, Moses, and his Lord. And the people of Moses said to him their famous word: (So go, you and your Lord, and fight. Indeed, here we are sitting) in this way, frankly and without distortion.

Moses realized that his people were no longer good for anything. The Pharaoh died, but his effects remain on the souls and require healing for a long time. Moses returned to his Lord telling him that he only owned himself and his brother. Moses prayed to his people that God would separate him from them.

God Almighty issued His judgment on this generation of the Children of Israel whose nature was corrupted. The sentence was forty years of wandering. Until this generation dies or reaches old age. In its place, another generation will be born, a generation that no one has defeated from within, and that will then be able to fight and win.

Cow story:

The days of wandering have begun. He started walking in a closed circle. You end where you begin, and you begin where you end. The journey begins to no destination. Day and night, morning and evening. They entered the wilderness at Sinai.

Moses stayed with his people calling them to God. It seems that their souls were twisted in an unmistakable way, and their stubbornness and stubbornness appear in what is known as the story of the cow. The issue did not require all these negotiations between them and Moses, nor did it require all this stubbornness. The origin of the story of the cow is that one day a rich man was found among the children of Israel, and his family quarreled, and they did not know who killed him. When they became exhausted, they turned to Moses so that he could seek refuge in his Lord. Moses turned to his Lord and commanded him to order his people to slaughter a cow. Here, the people were supposed to slaughter the first cow they came across. However, they began their negotiations forcefully. They accused Moses of mocking them and mocking them, and Moses sought refuge in God to be among the ignorant and mock them. I understand them that the solution to the issue lies in slaughtering a cow.

The matter here is a miracle, and has nothing to do with what is common in life, or what is usual among people. There is no relationship between slaughtering the cow and knowing the killer in the mysterious crime that occurred, but when did logical reasons govern the lives of the children of Israel? Supernatural miracles are the prevailing law in their lives, and their continuation in the case of the cow is not something that suggests wonder or raises astonishment.

But the children of Israel are the children of Israel. Just dealing with them meant it. The usual worldly matters and important matters of faith are equal to this. Whoever deals with any of the affairs of the children of Israel must suffer. Thus, Moses suffers from their harming him and accusing him of mocking them, then he tells them that he is serious about what he is telling them, and his command to slaughter a cow comes back, and the devious nature of the children of Israel reappears, the harshness and twisting returns, and they wonder: Is it an ordinary cow as we are accustomed to this type of animal? Or is it a unique creation with an advantage, so let Moses pray to his Lord to explain what it is. Moses calls on his Lord, and the emphasis on them increases, and the cow is identified more than before, as a middle cow. Not an old cow, not a young cow. Medium cow.

This is where the matter should have ended, but the negotiations are still continuing, and the evasion of the Children of Israel is still what rules the negotiating table. What color is a cow? Why did Moses call his Lord to ask him about the color of this cow? They do not take into account the requirements of politeness and dignity necessary for the right of God Almighty and the right of His noble Prophet, and how they should be ashamed of entrusting Moses with this repeated communication on a simple topic that does not deserve all this impudence and evasion. Moses asked his Lord and then told them about the color of the required cow. He says that it is a yellow cow, with a bright color that pleases onlookers.

Thus, the cow was identified as yellow, and despite the clarity of the matter, they returned to obstinacy and evasion. So God was harsh on them just as they were harsh on His Prophet and harmed him. They returned to asking Moses to pray to God to explain what it was, because cows looked similar to them, and Moses told them about a cow that was neither prepared for plowing nor for watering, free from defects, yellow with no blemish on it, meaning pure yellow. Their urgency ended up getting tougher. They began their search for a cow with these special qualities. Finally, they found it with an orphan, so they bought it and slaughtered it.

Moses grabbed part of the cow (its tongue, it was said) and hit the dead man with it, and he rose from his death. Moses asked him about his killer, so he told them about him (and it was said that he only pointed to the killer without speaking), then he returned to death. The children of Israel witnessed the miracle of reviving the dead before their eyes, and listened with their ears to the name of the killer. The mystery of the issue that had puzzled them for a long time due to their assertiveness and stubbornness was revealed.

We would like to draw the reader's attention to the people's poor manners with their Prophet and their Lord, and perhaps the Qur'anic context indicates this through their repetition of the word "your Lord" with which they address Moses. It would have been better for them to say to Moses, be polite, if it was necessary for them to say: (Pray for us your Lord) Pray for us our Lord. As for what they say to him: It is as if they limit the lordship of God Almighty to Moses. They remove themselves from the honor of servitude to God. Look at the verses how they suggest all of this. Then consider the context’s mockery of them simply by citing their saying: (Now you have brought the truth) after they had exhausted their Prophet back and forth between them and God Almighty, after they had exhausted their Prophet by asking him about the character of the cow, its color, its age, and its distinctive signs, after their obstinacy and God’s severity against them, They say to their Prophet when he brought to them something that is rare and rarely found in cows.

At that time they said to him: “Now you have brought the truth.” It was as if he was playing with them before that, and what came was not the truth from the first word to the last word. Then look at the shadows of the context and what it indicates of their injustice: (So they slaughtered it, but they were not about to do it.) Do not the shadows of the verses suggest to you their obstinacy, procrastination, their deviations, and their insistence on the truth? This wonderful painting indicates the position of the Children of Israel at the negotiating tables. It is their picture at the negotiating table with their noble Prophet Moses.

The children of Israel harmed Moses:

Moses suffered the most severe suffering from his people, suffered great hardship, and endured in conveying his message to them what he endured for the sake of God. Perhaps Moses' main problem was that he was sent to a people who had long been subjected to humiliation and humiliation, who had lived for a long time in an atmosphere devoid of freedom, and who had spent a long time in the midst of idolatry. Many different influences had succeeded in creating this twisted, helpless, and defeated psychology that was good for nothing. Except to torture its prophets and reformers.

The children of Israel tortured Moses with a torment that we, the people of this time, can understand its impact on Moses’ pure, sensitive, and generous soul. The torment was not limited to disobedience, stupidity, arrogance, ignorance, and idolatry, but it went beyond harming Moses personally. God Almighty said:

O you who have believed, do not be like those who annoyed Moses, but God cleared him of what they said, and he was of honor in the sight of God. (69) (Al-Ahzab)

We do not know the nature of this abuse, and we exclude the narration of some scholars in which they say that Moses was a lively man who always hid himself and did not like for anyone to see his body, so the Jews accused him of suffering from a skin disease or leprosy, so God wanted to clear him of what they said, so he went to take a bath one day and placed his clothes on a stone. Then he went out and found the stone running with his clothes and Moses running behind the stone naked until the children of Israel saw him naked and there was no blemish on his skin. We exclude this story due to its triviality, as it, along with the myth of the stone running with his clothes, does not give Moses his due respect, and it is inconsistent with his infallibility as a prophet.

We believe that the Jews psychologically harmed Moses. This is the harm that truly tears and hurts honorable souls. We do not know what this harm was, but we can imagine the ingenious and sinful extent to which the Children of Israel were capable of harming Moses. The wandering period:

Perhaps the greatest harm to Moses was the refusal of the Children of Israel to fight to spread the doctrine of monotheism on earth, or at the very least, to allow this doctrine to settle on earth in a place, to be safe, and to practice its worship in peace. The children of Israel refused to fight. And they said to Moses their famous word: (So go, you and your Lord, and fight. We are sitting here.)

With this mentality, God condemned them to wandering. The ruling was set for forty full years, and the children of Israel remained in the wilderness for forty years, until an entire generation perished. The lost, defeated generation perished from within, and a new generation was born in the loss of the diaspora and the cruelty of wandering. A generation that was not raised in a pagan climate, and whose spirit was not paralyzed by the lack of freedom. A generation that has not been defeated from within, a generation in which children can no longer understand why parents roam aimlessly in a wilderness with no apparent beginning and no apparent end. Except for fear of meeting the enemy. A generation that has become ready to pay the price for its humanity and dignity with its blood. A generation that does not say to Moses (Go, you and your Lord, and fight. Here we sit).

Another generation embraces the values ​​of military courage, as an important part of the fabric of any monotheistic religion. Finally, this generation was born in the midst of forty years of wandering.

It was destined for Moses. An increase in his suffering and a raise in his status before God Almighty. He was destined to not have his eyes darkened by the sight of this generation. Moses, peace and blessings be upon him, died before the children of Israel entered the land that God had decreed for them to enter.

The Messenger of God, may God bless him and grant him peace, said when his people were hurting him for the sake of God: Moses was hurt more than that, but he was patient.

Aaron died shortly before Moses. The death of Moses, peace and blessings be upon him, approached. He was still in the wilderness. He said, praying to his Lord: Lord, bring me closer to the Holy Land, a stone's throw away.

He would love to die close to the land he immigrated to. He urged his people to do so. But he could not, and he died in the wilderness. He was buried near a red dune. The last of God’s prophets on earth spoke about him when he was taken on a captivity. Muhammad, may God bless him and grant him peace, said: When I was on my journey, I passed by Moses while he was standing and praying in his grave by the Red Dune.

Regarding the death of Moses - peace be upon him - Al-Bukhari narrates in his Sahih on the authority of Abu Hurairah, may God be pleased with him: (The Angel of Death was sent to Moses, peace be upon them both, and when he came to him, he struck him in the face, hitting his eye and gouging it out - so he returned to his Lord, and said: You sent me to a servant who did not want to die, and God returned his eye to him, and said: Go back, and tell him to place his hand on the back of a bull - meaning the back of a bull -, for everything with which his hand was covered with every hair is a year. He said: Oh Lord, then what? He said: Then death. He said: Now, he asked God to bring him close to the Holy Land, a stone's throw away. He said: The Messenger of God, may God bless him and grant him peace, said: (If I were then, I would show you his grave, next to the road, by the red dune).

Moses - peace and blessings be upon him - died in the wilderness, and Joshua bin Nun took charge of the Children of Israel.

Moses and the righteous servant:

God Almighty said:

And when Musa said to his servant, “I will not leave until I reach the gathering of the two Bahrains, or I will spend a period of time.” (60) (Al-Kahf)

Moses - peace be upon him - had a goal for this journey that he intended, and he intended something behind it, He declares his determination to reach the Bahrain complex, no matter the difficulty, and no matter how long it takes to reach it. He expresses this determination by saying (or I will go on for a while).

We see that the Holy Qur’an does not specify for us the place where the events took place, nor does it specify the date for us, nor does it reveal the names. He did not clarify the nature of the righteous servant whom Moses met. Was he a prophet or a messenger? Or a scientist? Or my guardian?

The commentators differed in determining the place. It was said that it was the sea of ​​Persia and the Romans, and it was said that it was the Sea of ​​Jordan or Qalzam, and it was said that it was at Tangier, and it was said that it was in Africa, and it was said that it was the Sea of ​​Andalusia.. The evidence is not based on the authenticity of any of these places, and if specifying the place was required, God Almighty would have specified it... Rather, the Qur’anic context has made the place vague, just as it has made the time vague, just as it has made the names of people blurry due to a higher wisdom.

The story relates to a science that is not our science based on causes... nor is it the science of the prophets based on revelation... rather we are faced with a science of a most mysterious nature... the science of the highest destiny, and that is a science over which thick curtains have been drawn... the place of the meeting is unknown, as we have seen... and the time of the meeting is also unknown... We do not know when Moses met this servant.

And so the story goes on without its lines specifying for you the place or time of events. The Qur’anic context also conceals the name of its most important hero. The Truth, Blessed and Most High, refers to him by saying: (A servant from among Our servants to whom We have given mercy from Us and whom We have taught knowledge from Ourselves) is a servant whose name the Qur’anic context has hidden.. This The servant is the one whom Moses seeks to learn from.

God Almighty singled out His noble Prophet Moses - peace be upon him - with many things. He is the speaker of God Almighty, one of the most powerful of the messengers, the owner of the miracle of the stick and the hand, and the prophet to whom the Torah was revealed without any intermediary, but God spoke to him verbally. This great prophet turns in the story into a humble student of knowledge who tolerates his teacher to learn. And who can be his teacher other than this servant whose name goes beyond the Qur’anic context, even if the purified Sunnah tells us that he is Al-Khidr - peace be upon him - just as it told us that the boy is Joshua the son of Nun, and Moses walks with him? The servant who receives his knowledge from God without the reasons for receiving it that we know.

Despite Musa's great status, Al-Khidr refuses to accompany Musa. He makes him understand that he will not be able to be patient with him. Then he agrees to accompany him on the condition that Musa does not ask him about anything until Al-Khidr tells him about it.

Al-Khidr is the mysterious silence itself. He does not speak, and his actions arouse the deep astonishment of Moses. There are actions that Al-Khidr does that rise before Moses’ eyes to the level of crimes and disasters. There are actions that seem meaningless to Moses. Al-Khidr’s actions arouse Moses’ astonishment and opposition. Despite Moses' knowledge and rank, he found himself deeply confused by the actions of this servant to whom God had given knowledge from Himself.

The scholars differed regarding Al-Khidr: some of them considered him to be one of God’s saints, and some of them considered him a prophet... Legends have woven themselves around his life and existence, and it was said that he will still be alive until the Day of Resurrection, and it is an issue that has not been mentioned in texts or traces in which he can be trusted, so we can only say that he died as the servants of God die... and the issue of his guardianship, or prophethood, remains. We will postpone the discussion on this issue until we look into his story as mentioned in the Holy Qur’an.

Moses preached to the Children of Israel, calling them to God and speaking to them about the truth, and it seemed that his speech was comprehensive and wonderful. After he finished his speech, one of the children of Israel listening asked him: Is there anyone on the face of the earth more knowledgeable than you, O Prophet of God?
Musa said impulsively: No.
God Almighty blamed Moses when he did not return knowledge to him, so he sent Gabriel to him asking him: O Moses, how do you know where God places his knowledge?
Moses realized that he was hasty. Gabriel, peace be upon him, came back and said to him: There is a servant of God in the Bahrain complex who is more knowledgeable than you.

Moses' honorable soul longed to increase knowledge, and his intention was set on leaving to accompany this knowledgeable servant. He asked how he could get to him. So he was ordered to leave, and to carry with him a whale in a cage, that is, a fish in a basket. And in this place where the life of this whale bounces back and leaks into the sea, he will find the knowledgeable servant. Moses - the seeker of knowledge - set off with his boy. The boy carried a whale in a basket. They set out in search of the knowledgeable, righteous slave. They have no sign of the place where he is, except for the miracle of the fish in the basket rebounding to life and leaking into the sea.

It appears that Moses - peace be upon him - was determined to find this knowledgeable servant, even if he had to travel for ages and ages. It was said that the era is a year, and it was said that it is eighty years. However, it is an expression of design, not specifically duration.

The two arrived at a rock next to the sea. Moses lay down and fell asleep, while the boy remained awake. The wind threw one of the waves onto the shore, and a spray hit the whale, and it came to life and jumped into the sea. (So ​​he took his path in the sea as a swarm)... The whale leaking into the sea was a sign that God informed Moses of to determine the place of his meeting with the wise man from whom Moses came to learn.

Moses woke up from his sleep and did not notice that the whale had leaked into the sea. And his boy who was accompanying him forgot to tell him about what happened to the whale. And Moses walked with his boy for the rest of their day and night, forgetting about their whale. Then Moses remembered his lunch and fatigue came over him.. (He said to his boy, “Bring us our lunch. We have met this from our journey.” accusative).. What happened flashed in the boy's mind.

At that time, the boy remembered how the whale had leaked into the sea there.. He told Moses what had happened, and he apologized to him that Satan had forgotten to mention to him what had happened, despite the strangeness of what had happened, for the whale had taken (a wondrous path in the sea)... It was a strange thing what Joshua bin Nun saw. He saw the whale parting the water and leaving a mark like a bird writhing on the sand.

Musa walked from the whale’s passage to the sea and said, “That is what we wanted.” This is what we wanted. The whale’s leak determines the place where we will meet the knowledgeable man. Musa and his two boys retreat, retracing their trail and returning. Look at the beginning of the story, and how it is very ambiguous and vague.

Finally, Moses reached the place from which the whale had leaked. They reached the rock where they slept, and then the whale leaked from the basket into the sea. And there they found a man.

Al-Bukhari says that Musa and his servant found Al-Khidr lying covered in his garment...with one end under his feet and one end under his head.

So Moses greeted him, then he revealed his face and said: Is there peace on your land..? Who are you?
Moses said: I am Moses.
Al-Khidr said: Moses of the Children of Israel... Peace be upon you, O Prophet of Israel.
Musa said: What do you know about me?
Al-Khidr said: The one who recognized me and directed you to me.. What do you want, Musa?
Moses said, gently and exaggeratedly in reverence: (Shall I follow you on the condition that you teach people of what you have been taught, in the right way?)
Al-Khidr said: Is it not enough for you that the Torah is in your hands... and that the revelation comes to you...? O Moses (You will not be able to be patient with me).

We want to pause for a moment to notice the difference between Musa’s flattering, exaggerated question regarding politeness... and Al-Khidr’s decisive response, which Musa understood that his knowledge was not something that Musa should have known, just as Musa’s knowledge was knowledge that Al-Khidr did not know... The interpreters say that Al-Khidr said to Musa: My knowledge you do not know... You will not be able to be patient with him, because the phenomena by which you will judge my knowledge will not heal your heart or give you an explanation, and perhaps you have seen in my behavior what you do not understand the reason for or know the cause of.. So you will not be patient with my knowledge, O Moses.

Moses endured the harsh words of the repulse and again begged him to allow him to accompany him and learn from him. Moses told him, in what he said, that he would find him, God willing, patient and not disobeying him.

Consider how God’s Word humbles Himself and assures the hidden servant that He will not disobey His command. Al-Khidr said to Moses - peace be upon them - that there was a condition he required for him to accept that Moses accompany him and learn from him, which was that he should not ask him about anything until he told him about it.. So Moses agreed to the condition and they set off..

Musa set off with Al-Khidr, walking on the seashore. A ship passed by, so Al-Khidr and Musa asked its owners to carry them. The ship’s owners recognized Al-Khidr, so they picked him up and carried Musa without pay, out of respect for Al-Khidr. Musa was surprised when the ship docked and its owners and passengers left. He was surprised that Al-Khidr was left behind. Its owners had barely moved away when Al-Khidr began to break the ship. He uprooted one of its boards and threw it into the sea, and the waves carried it away.

Moses denounced Al-Khidr’s actions. The owners of the ship carried us without reward. They honored us. And here he is, breaching their ship and ruining it. The behavior from Moses’ point of view was defective. Moses’ impulsive nature overcame him, and his zeal for the truth moved him, so he rushed to talk to his professor and teacher, forgetting the condition he had imposed on him: (He said, “You broke it to drown its people. You have come.” Something terrible.) Here the divine servant draws the attention of Moses to the futility of trying to teach him, because he will not be able to be patient with him (He said, “Did I not say that you would not be able to be patient with me?”), and Moses apologizes for forgetfulness and hopes that he will not blame him or burden him (He said, “Do not hold me accountable for what I have forgotten, and do not burden me.” My affair is difficult.)

They walked together... and they passed by a garden where boys were playing... until when they got tired of playing, each one of them turned aside and fell asleep... Moses was surprised that the divine servant was killing a boy... and Moses became angry, asking about the crime this boy had committed to kill him like this... The divine servant again reminds him that he made him understand that he will not be able to be patient with him (He said, “Did I not tell you that you would not be able to be patient with me?”)... Moses apologizes that he forgot and will not ask again, and if he asks him again, he will have the right to separate from him (He said, “If I ask you about anything after that, then do not Accompany me. You have attained an excuse from me.)

Musa went on with Al-Khidr. They entered a stingy village. Musa does not know why they went to the village, nor does he know why they spent the night there. They ran out of food, so they asked the villagers for food, but they refused to host them. Evening came upon them, and the two of them took shelter in an empty space in which there was a wall that wanted to collapse. The wall was collapsing and was about to fall. Musa was surprised that the worshiping man got up to spend the whole night repairing the wall and building it again. Musa was astonished by the behavior of his companion and teacher. The village was stingy, and the people in it did not deserve this free work. The phrase: Abdullah said to Moses: (This is a separation between you and me).

The divine servant Moses warned against the consequences of asking questions. Now comes the turn for interpretation.

All the actions of the divine servant that aroused and perplexed Moses, when he did them, did not come from His command. He was executing a higher will. This higher will had its hidden wisdom, and the actions indicated apparent cruelty, while their reality concealed tender mercy. Thus, disasters in this world sometimes conceal the essence of mercy, and blessings wear the clothes of calamities and are good at disguising themselves. Thus, the apparent matter and its hidden contradiction, and Moses, despite his enormous knowledge, knew not more than a drop of the servant’s knowledge. Divine, The divine servant does not know of God’s knowledge except to the extent that a bird that wets its beak in the sea takes from the sea water..

The divine servant revealed to Moses two things at the same time: He revealed to him that his knowledge - that is, the knowledge of Moses - was limited... He also revealed to him that many of the calamities that occur on earth conceal a great mercy in their black, gloomy robe.

The owners of the ship will consider the breach of their ship to be a calamity that has come to them, while it is a blessing disguised as a calamity... a blessing that will not reveal its face until war breaks out and the king forcibly confiscates all existing ships, then releases this damaged, defective ship... Thus, their family’s source of livelihood remains the same, so they do not die of hunger.

Also, the father and mother of the murdered child will consider that a catastrophe has befallen them to kill their innocent little one... However, his death represents a great mercy for them, for God will give them in his place a boy who will take care of them in their old age and not exhaust them with tyranny and disbelief like the murdered boy. Thus, grace disappears in the clothes of adversity, mercy wears the mask of disaster, and the outside of things differs from their inside until the Prophet of God, Moses, invokes an action taking place before him, and then a servant of God draws him to the wisdom of the action, its significance, and the total mercy of God, which hides itself behind many masks.

As for the wall that he had exhausted himself to erect, without asking for payment from the villagers, he was hiding under it the treasure of two weak orphan boys in the city. If he had left the wall to collapse, the treasure would have appeared beneath it, and the two little ones would not have been able to push it away. Because their father was good, God benefited them through his goodness during their childhood and weakness. He wanted them to grow up, strengthen their strength, and extract their treasure while being able to protect it.

Then the man hands off the matter. It is God's mercy that required this action. It is God's command, not his command. He informed him of the unseen in this matter and before it, and directed him to deal with it according to what he had shown him of the unseen.

And this good servant disappeared.. He went into the unknown just as he came out of the unknown.. However, Moses learned two important lessons from his company:

He learned not to be deceived by his knowledge of Sharia law, for there is knowledge of truth.

He learned not to frown in his heart at human misfortunes, for perhaps the creative hand of mercy was hiding its secret of kindness, salvation, and comfort behind the masks of sadness, pain, and death.

These are the lessons that Moses, the custodian of God Almighty and His Messenger, learned from this servant who was hidden in secret. Now who is the owner of this knowledge then..? Is he a saint or a prophet?

Many Sufis believe that this divine servant is one of the saints of God Almighty. God imparted to him part of his earthly knowledge without the known reasons for the transmission of knowledge. Some scholars believe that this righteous servant was a prophet. Those who hold this opinion argue that the context of the story indicates his prophethood in several ways:

1. One of them is the Almighty’s saying:

Then they found a servant from among Our servants to whom We had given mercy from Us and to whom We had taught knowledge from Our own generation. (65) (Al-Kahf)

2. The second is what Moses said to him:

Moses said to him, “Shall I follow you on the condition that you teach me of what you have been taught of righteousness?” (66) He said, “You will never be able to be patient with me.” (67) How can you be patient unless you are humbled? (68) He said, “You will find me, God willing, patient, and I will not disobey you in any command.” (69) He said, “Then if you follow me, do not ask me about anything until I narrate it to you.” Remembrance (70) (Al-Kahf)

If he had been a saint and not a prophet, Moses would not have addressed him in this way, and he would not have given Moses this response. If he had not been a prophet, this would have meant that he was not infallible, and there would have been no motive for Moses, who was the great prophet and possessor of infallibility, to seek knowledge from a guardian other than the duty of infallibility.

3. The third is that Al-Khidr proceeded to kill that boy with inspiration from God and a command from him... This is independent evidence of his prophecy, and clear proof of his infallibility, because it is not permissible for a guardian to attempt to kill souls simply because of what comes to his mind, because his thoughts are not obligatory to be infallible... as it is permissible for him to make a mistake by consensus... So, in Al-Khidr’s intention to kill the boy is evidence of his prophecy.

4. The fourth is what Al-Khidr said to Moses:

A mercy from your Lord, and what you have done is my command.

It means that what I did I did not do on my own initiative, but rather something I was commanded to do by God and revealed to me about it.

The scholars saw that Al-Khidr was a prophet, while the servants and Sufis saw that he was one of God’s saints.

Among Al-Khidr’s words that the Sufis reported about him are the words of Wahb ibn Munabbih: Al-Khidr said: O Moses, people are tormented in this world according to the extent of their concerns in it. And Bishr bin Al-Harith Al-Hafi said: Moses said to Al-Khidr: Advise me.. Al-Khidr said: May God make it easy for you to obey Him.

We tend to consider him a prophet due to his worldly knowledge, but we do not find a text in the context of the Qur’an about his prophecy, and we do not find a text that prevents him from considering him as a guardian to whom God gave some of his worldly knowledge. Perhaps this ambiguity about his honorable person came intentionally, to serve the original goal of the story. We will stick to our place and do not go beyond him and dispute about his prophethood or his guardianship. And if we mention him in the context of God’s prophets, because he was a teacher to Moses.. and a teacher for a period. Of time.

Qarun and the people of Moses:

The Qur’an tells us the story of Qarun, who was from the people of Moses. But the Qur’an does not specify the time or place of the story. Did this story happen with the children of Israel and Moses in Egypt before the Exodus? Or did it occur after the Exodus during the life of Moses? Or did it occur among the Children of Israel after Moses? Aside from the different narrations, we present the story as mentioned in the Holy Qur’an.

God tells us about the treasures of Qarun, and God Almighty says that the keys to the rooms that contained the treasures were difficult for a group of strong men to carry. If we knew about the keys to the treasures in this situation, what were the treasures themselves like?! But Qarun transgressed against his people after God gave him wealth. The Qur’an does not mention what the transgression was, leaving it unknown and including various forms. Perhaps he wronged them by oppressing them and usurping their land and possessions. Perhaps he wronged them by depriving them of their right to that money. The right of the poor to the money of the rich. Perhaps he wronged them for reasons other than these.

It seems that the wise people among his people advised him to be intentional and moderate, which is the correct approach. They warn him against joy that leads to its owner forgetting who is blessed with this money, and they advise him to enjoy the money in this world, without forgetting the afterlife, so he must work for the hereafter with this money. They remind him that this money is a gift from God and a benevolence, so he must do well and give this money in charity, so that he can return the benevolence with benevolence. They warn him against corruption on earth, through transgression, injustice, envy, hatred, and spending money for purposes other than its intended purpose, or withholding from what should be in it. God does not like spoilers.

Qarun’s response was one sentence that carried various meanings of corruption (He said, “I was given it based on knowledge that I have.”) His arrogance made him forget the source and wisdom of this blessing, and he became tempted by money and blinded by wealth. Qarun did not listen to the call of his people, nor did he feel the blessing of his Lord.

One day, Qarun went out to his people, fully dressed, and the hearts of some of the people were filled with joy, and they wished that they had what Qarun had been given, and they felt that he was in great blessing. The people of knowledge and faith who heard them responded to them: Woe to you, you deceived ones. Beware of temptation, fear God, and know that God’s reward is better than this adornment, and what God has is better than what Qarun has.

When the temptation of adornment reaches its climax, and souls falter and collapse before it, divine power intervenes to put an end to the temptation, have mercy on the people weak from its temptation, and destroy vanity and pride, so the punishment comes decisively (So We caused the earth to swallow him and his house). Thus, in a fleeting flash, the earth swallowed him and his house. He went weak and helpless, with no one to support him, nor to achieve victory with prestige or money.

People began to talk to each other in astonishment, wonder, and consideration. Those who wished that they had Qarun’s money, authority, adornment, and luck in this world said: Truly, God Almighty extends sustenance to whomever He pleases among His servants and expands upon them, or takes it away. Praise be to God for granting us grace and protecting us from loss and painful torment. We have turned to You, Glory be to You. Praise be to You in the first and the hereafter.

نبذة:

أخو موسى ورفيقه في دعوة فرعون إلى الإيمان بالله لأنه كان فصيحا ومتحدثا، استخلفه موسى على قومه عندما ذهب للقاء الله فوق جبل الطور، ولكن حدثت فتنة السامري الذي حول بني إسرائيل إلى عبادة عجل من الذهب له خوار ، فدعاهم هارون إلى الرجوع لعبادة الله بدلا من العجل ولكنهم استكبروا فلما رجع موسى ووجد ما آل إليه قومه عاتب هارون عتابا شديدا.

سيرته:

لا يذكر الكثير عن سيرة هارون عليه السلام. إلا أن المعلوم هو أن الله أيد موسى بأخيه هارون في دعوته فلقد كان هارون عليه السلام أفصح لسانا. وورد موقف موسى عليه السلام من أخيه حين استخلفه على بني إسرائيل وذهب للقاء ربه، فعبدت بنو إسرائيل العجل الذي صنعه السامري. القصة مذكورة بتفاصيلها في قصة موسى عليه السلام.
number-en: The story of Aaron, peace be upon him
label-en:
About:

Moses' brother and companion in calling on Pharaoh to believe in God because he was eloquent and a speaker. Moses appointed him as his successor over his people when he went to meet God on Mount Tur, but the temptation of the Samaritan occurred, who converted the children of Israel to worship a golden calf that had a bellowing sound, so Aaron called on them to return to worshiping God instead of the calf, but they were arrogant. When Moses returned and found what his people had become, he severely rebuked Aaron.

His biography:

Not much is mentioned about the biography of Aaron, peace be upon him. However, what is known is that God supported Moses with his brother Aaron in his calling, as Aaron, peace be upon him, had the most eloquent tongue. The position of Moses, peace be upon him, towards his brother was reported when he appointed him as successor over the Children of Israel and went to meet his Lord, so the Children of Israel worshiped the calf that the Samaritan had made. The story is mentioned in detail in the story of Moses, peace be upon him.

number: قصة يوشع بن نون عليه السلام
label:
نبذة:

ورد أنه الفتى الذي صاحب موسى للقاء الخضر. وهو النبي الذي أخرج الله على يديه بني إسرائي من صحراء سيناء، وحاربوا أهل فلسطين وانتصروا عليهم.

سيرته:

لم يخرج أحد من التيه ممن كان مع موسى. سوى اثنين. هما الرجلان اللذان أشارا على ملأ بني إسرائيل بدخول قرية الجبارين. ويقول المفسرون: إن أحدهما يوشع بن نون. وهذا هو فتى موسى في قصته مع الخضر. صار الآن نبيا من أنبياء بني إسرائيل، وقائدا لجيش يتجه نحو الأرض التي أمرهم الله بدخولها.

خرج يوشع بن نون ببني إسرائيل من التيه، بعد أربعين سنة، وقصد بهم الأرض المقدسة. ,كانت هذه الأربعين سنة -كما يقول العلماء- كفيلة بأن يموت فيها جميع من خرج مع موسى عليه السلام من مصر، ويبقى جيل جديد تربى على أيادي موسى وهارون ويوشع بن نون، جيل يقيم الصلا ويؤتي الزكاة ويؤمن بالله ورسله. قطع بهم نهر الأردن إلى أريحا، وكانت من أحصن المدائن سورا وأعلاها قصورا وأكثرها أهلا. فحاصرها ستة أشهر.

وروي في صحيح مسلم أن رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم قال: ‏(غزا نبي من الأنبياء فقال لقومه لا يتبعني رجل قد ملك ‏ ‏بضع ‏ ‏امرأة وهو يريد أن ‏ ‏يبني ‏ ‏بها ولما ‏ ‏يبن ‏ ‏ولا آخر قد بنى بنيانا ولما يرفع سقفها ولا آخر قد اشترى غنما أو ‏ ‏خلفات ‏ ‏وهو منتظر ولادها قال فغزا ‏ ‏فأدنى ‏ ‏للقرية ‏ ‏حين صلاة العصر أو قريبا من ذلك فقال للشمس أنت مأمورة وأنا مأمور اللهم احبسها علي شيئا فحبست عليه حتى فتح الله عليه قال فجمعوا ما غنموا فأقبلت النار لتأكله فأبت أن ‏ ‏تطعمه ‏ ‏فقال فيكم ‏ ‏غلول ‏ ‏فليبايعني من كل قبيلة رجل فبايعوه فلصقت يد رجل بيده فقال فيكم ‏ ‏الغلول ‏ ‏فلتبايعني قبيلتك فبايعته قال فلصقت بيد رجلين أو ثلاثة فقال فيكم ‏ ‏الغلول ‏ ‏أنتم ‏ ‏غللتم ‏ ‏قال فأخرجوا له مثل رأس بقرة من ذهب قال فوضعوه في المال وهو ‏ ‏بالصعيد ‏ ‏فأقبلت النار فأكلته فلم تحل الغنائم لأحد من قبلنا ذلك بأن الله تبارك وتعالى رأى ضعفنا وعجزنا فطيبها لنا) ويرى العلماء أن هذا النبي هو يوشع بن نون، فقد كان اليهود لا يعملون ولا يحاربون يوم السبت، وعندما خشي أن يذهب النصر إذا توقف اليهود عن القتال، فدعى الله أن يحبس الشمس. واخْتـُلِفَ في حبس الشمس المذكور هنا, فقيل: ردت على أدراجها, وقيل: وقفت ولم ترد, وقيل: أبطئ بحركتها, وكل ذلك من معجزات النبوة .

صدر الأمر الإلهي لبني إسرائيل أن يدخلوا المدينة سجدا.. أي راكعين مطأطئي رءوسهم شاكرين لله عز وجل ما من به عليهم من الفتح. أمروا أن يقولوا حال دخولهم: (حِطَّةٌ).. بمعنى حط عنا خطايانا التي سلفت، وجنبنا الذي تقدم من آبائنا.

إلا أن بني إسرائيل خالف ما أمرت به قولا وفعلا.. فدخلوا الباب متعالين متكبرين، وبدلوا قولا غير الذي قيل لهم.. فأصابهم عذاب من الله بما ظلموا. كانت جريمة الآباء هي الذل، وأصبحت جريمة الأبناء الكبرياء والافتراء.

ولم تكن هذه الجريمة هي أول جرائم بني إسرائيل ولا آخر جرائمهم، فقد عذبوا رسلهم كثيرا بعد موسى، وتحولت التوراة بين أيديهم إلى قراطيس يبدون بعضها ويخفون كثيرا. حسبما تقتضي الأحوال وتدفع المصلحة المباشرة، وكان هذا الجحود هو المسؤول عما أصاب بني إسرائيل من عقوبات.

عاد بنو إسرائيل إلى ظلمهم لأنفسهم.. اعتقدوا أنهم شعب الله المختار، وتصوروا انطلاقا من هذا الاعتقاد أن من حقهم ارتكاب أي شيء وكل شيء.. وعظمت فيهم الأخطاء وتكاثرت الخطايا وامتدت الجرائم بعد كتابهم إلى أنبيائهم، فقتلوا من قتلوا من الأنبياء.

وسلط الله عليهم بعد رحمة الأنبياء قسوة الملوك الجبارين، يظلمونهم ويسفكون دمائهم، وسلط الله أعدائهم عليهم ومكن لهم من رقابهم وأموالهم.

وكان معهم تابوت الميثاق. وهو تابوت يضم بقية مما ترك موسى وهارون، ويقال إن هذا التابوت كان يضم ما بقي من ألواح التوراة التي أنزلت على موسى ونجت من يد الزمان. وكان لهذا التابوت بركة تمتد إلى حياتهم وحروبهم، فكان وجود التابوت بينهم في الحرب، يمدهم بالسكينة والثبات، ويدفعهم إلى النصر، فلما ظلموا أنفسهم ورفعت التوراة من قلوبهم لم يعد هناك معنى لبقاء نسختها معهم، وهكذا ضاع منهم تابوت العهد، وضاع في حرب من حروبهم التي هزموا فيها.

وساءت أحوال بني إسرائيل بسبب ذنوبهم وتعنتهم وظلمهم لأنفسهم. ومرت سنوات وسنوات. واشتدت الحاجة إلى ظهور نبي ينتشلهم من الوهدة السحيقة التي أوصلتهم إليها فواجع الآثام وكبائر الخطايا.
number-en: The story of Joshua bin Nun, peace be upon him
label-en:
About:

It was reported that he was the boy who accompanied Musa to meet Al-Khidr. He is the prophet through whom God brought the Israelites out of the Sinai desert, and they fought the people of Palestine and defeated them.

His biography:

No one who was with Moses emerged from the wandering. Only two. They are the two men who advised the children of Israel to enter the village of Jabareen. The commentators say: One of them is Joshua bin Nun. This is Musa's boy in his story with Al-Khidr. He now became one of the prophets of the children of Israel, and the leader of an army heading towards the land that God had commanded them to enter.

Joshua bin Nun led the children of Israel out of the wilderness, after forty years, and headed with them to the Holy Land. These forty years - as scholars say - were enough for everyone who left Egypt to die with Moses, peace be upon him, and a new generation would remain who was raised at the hands of Moses, Aaron, and Joshua bin Nun, a generation that would perform prayers, pay zakat, and believe in God and His messengers. The Jordan River crossed them to Jericho, which was one of the cities with the most fortified walls, the tallest palaces, and the most populous. He besieged it for six months.

It was narrated in Sahih Muslim that the Messenger of God, may God’s prayers and peace be upon him, said: “One of the prophets fought and said to his people: ‘A man who owns a woman’s possessions and wants to build with her will not follow me, nor will he build a building with her, nor another who has built a building and will not raise its roof, nor another who has bought sheep or offspring and is waiting for them to give birth.’ He said, ‘He fought. So he approached the village during the afternoon prayer or close to that, and he said to the sun, “You are commanded, and I am commanded. Oh God, hold it back for something.” So it held back until God granted it victory. He said, “They gathered what they had seized, and the fire came to consume it, but it refused to feed it.” So he said, “There is exaggeration in you.” Let a man from each tribe pledge allegiance to me, so they pledged their allegiance to him. A man’s hand joined his hand, and he said: Among you are the unrighteous ones. So let your tribe pledge allegiance to me. So I pledged allegiance to him. He said, so I joined the hand of two or three men, and he said: Among you are the unrighteous ones. You are untipped. He said: So they brought out for him something like a golden cow’s head. He said: So they put it in the money while he was in Upper Egypt. So I came. The fire consumed it, and the spoils were not lawful for anyone before us. This is because God, Blessed and Most High, saw our weakness and inability, and so granted it to us.) Scholars believe that this prophet is Joshua bin Nun, as the Jews did not work or fight on the Sabbath, and when he feared that victory would be lost if the Jews stopped fighting, So he prayed to God to block the sun. There was disagreement regarding the imprisonment of the sun mentioned here. It was said: It returned its steps, and it was said: It stood and did not return, and it was said: It slowed down its movement, and all of that is one of the miracles of prophecy.

The divine command was issued to the Children of Israel to enter the city prostrating... that is, kneeling with their heads bowed, thankful to God Almighty for the conquest He had bestowed upon them. They were ordered to say as soon as they entered: (Hittah)... meaning, remove from us our sins that have passed, and protect us from what came before from our fathers.

However, the children of Israel disobeyed what I was commanded in word and deed, so they entered the door arrogant and haughty, and changed what they said other than what was said to them. So a punishment from God befell them because of their wrongdoing. The crime of the fathers was humiliation, and the crime of the children became pride and slander.

This crime was not the first crime of the Children of Israel nor their last, as they tortured their messengers many times after Moses, and the Torah was transformed in their hands into letters, some of which they revealed and much of which they concealed. As circumstances required and the direct interest motivated, this ingratitude was responsible for the punishments that befell the children of Israel.

The children of Israel returned to their oppression of themselves. They believed that they were God’s chosen people, and based on this belief, they imagined that they had the right to commit anything and everything. Mistakes became great among them, sins multiplied, and crimes spread after their book to their prophets, so they killed whomever of the prophets they killed.

After the mercy of the prophets, God imposed on them the cruelty of tyrannical kings, who oppressed them and shed their blood, and God empowered their enemies over them and granted them their slaves and their money.

They had with them the ark of the covenant. It is a coffin that contains the rest of what Moses and Aaron left behind. It is said that this coffin contained what remained of the tablets of the Torah that were revealed to Moses and survived the hand of time. This ark had a blessing that extended to their lives and their wars. The presence of the ark among them in war provided them with tranquility and steadfastness, and pushed them to victory. When they wronged themselves and the Torah was removed from their hearts, there was no longer any meaning for its copy to remain with them, and thus the Ark of the Covenant was lost from them, and it was lost in one of their wars in which they were defeated.

The conditions of the Children of Israel worsened because of their sins, stubbornness, and injustice towards themselves. Years and years passed. The need became intense for the appearance of a prophet who would rescue them from the abyss into which the calamities of misdeeds and major sins had led them.

label:
نبذة:

‏‏آتاه الله العلم والحكمة وسخر له الجبال والطير يسبحن معه وألان له الحديد، كان عبدا خالصا لله شكورا يصوم يوما ويفطر يوما يقوم نصف الليل وينام ثلثه ويقوم سدسه وأنزل الله عليه الزبور وقد أوتي ملكا عظيما وأمره الله أن يحكم بالعدل.

سيرته:

حال بنو إسرائيل قبل داود:

قبل البدء بقصة داود عليه السلام، لنرى الأوضاع التي عاشها بنو إسرائل في تلك الفترة.

لقد انفصل الحكم عن الدين..فآخر نبي ملك كان يوشع بن نون.. أما من بعده فكانت الملوك تسوس بني إسرائيل وكانت الأنبياء تهديهم. وزاد طغيان بني إسرائيل، فكانوا يقتلون الأنبياء، نبيا تلو نبي، فسلط الله عليهم ملوكا منهم ظلمة جبارين، ألوهم وطغوا عليهم.

وتتالت الهزائم على بني إسرائيل، حتى انهم أضاعوا التابوت. وكان في التابوت بقية مما ترك آل موسى وهارون، فقيل أن فيها بقية من الألواح التي أنزلها الله على موسى، وعصاه، وأمورا آخرى. كان بنو إسرائيل يأخذون التابوت معهم في معاركهم لتحل عليهم السكينة ويحققوا النصر. فتشروا وساءت حالهم.

في هذه الظروف الصعبة، كانت هنالك امرأة حامل تدعو الله كثيرا أن يرزقها ولدا ذكرا. فولدت غلاما فسمته أشموئيل.. ومعناه بالعبرانية إسماعيل.. أي سمع الله دعائي.. فلما ترعرع بعثته إلى المسجد وأسلمته لرجل صالح ليتعلم منه الخير والعبادة. فكان عنده، فلما بلغ أشده، بينما هو ذات ليلة نائم: إذا صوت يأتيه من ناحية المسجد فانتبه مذعورا ظانا أن الشيخ يدعوه. فهرع أشموئيل إلى يسأله: أدعوتني..؟ فكره الشيخ أن يفزعه فقال: نعم.. نم.. فنام..

ثم ناداه الصوت مرة ثانية.. وثالثة. وانتبه إلى جبريل عليه السلام يدعوه: إن ربك بعثك إلى قومك.

اختيار طالوت ملكا:

ذهب بنو إسرائيل لنبيهم يوما.. سألوه: ألسنا مظلومين؟
قال: بلى..
قالوا: ألسنا مشردين؟
قال: بلى..
قالوا: ابعث لنا ملكا يجمعنا تحت رايته كي نقاتل في سبيل الله ونستعيد أرضنا ومجدنا.
قال نبيهم وكان أعلم بهم: هل أنتم واثقون من القتال لو كتب عليكم القتال؟
قالوا: ولماذا لا نقاتل في سبيل الله، وقد طردنا من ديارنا، وتشرد أبناؤنا، وساء حالنا؟
قال نبيهم: إن الله اختار لكم طالوت ملكا عليكم.
قالوا: كيف يكون ملكا علينا وهو ليس من أبناء الأسرة التي يخرج منها الملوك -أبناء يهوذا- كما أنه ليس غنيا وفينا من هو أغنى منه؟
قال نبيهم: إن الله اختاره، وفضله عليكم بعلمه وقوة جسمه.
قالوا: ما هي آية ملكه؟
قال لهم نبيهم: يسرجع لكم التابوت تجمله الملائكة.

ووقعت هذه المعجزة.. وعادت إليهم التوراة يوما.. ثم تجهز جيش طالوت، وسار الجيش طويلا حتى أحس الجنود بالعطش.. قال الملك طالوت لجنوده: سنصادف نهرا في الطريق، فمن شرب منه فليخرج من الجيش، ومن لم يذقه وإنما بل ريقه فقط فليبق معي في الجيش..

وجاء النهر فشرب معظم الجنود، وخرجوا من الجيش، وكان طالوت قد أعد هذا الامتحان ليعرف من يطيعه من الجنود ومن يعصاه، وليعرف أيهم قوي الإرادة ويتحمل العطش، وأيهم ضعيف الإرادة ويستسلم بسرعة. لم يبق إلا ثلاثمئة وثلاثة عشر رجلا، لكن جميعهم من الشجعان.

كان عدد أفراد جيش طالوت قليلا، وكان جيش العدو كبيرا وقويا.. فشعر بعض -هؤلاء الصفوة- أنهم أضعف من جالوت وجيشه وقالوا: كيف نهزم هذا الجيش الجبار..؟‍‍‍‍‍‍‍‍‍!

قال المؤمنون من جيش طالوت: النصر ليس بالعدة والعتاد، إنما النصر من عند الله.. (كَم مِّن فِئَةٍ قَلِيلَةٍ غَلَبَتْ فِئَةً كَثِيرَةً بِإِذْنِ اللّهِ).. فثبّتوهم.

وبرز جالوت في دروعه الحديدية وسلاحه، وهو يطلب أحدا يبارزه.. وخاف منه جنود طالوت جميعا.. وهنا برز من جيش طالوت راعي غنم صغير هو داود.. كان داود مؤمنا بالله، وكان يعلم أن الإيمان بالله هو القوة الحقيقية في هذا الكون، وأن العبرة ليست بكثرة السلاح، ولا ضخامة الجسم ومظهر الباطل.

وكان الملك، قد قال: من يقتل جالوت يصير قائدا على الجيش ويتزوج ابنتي.. ولم يكن داود يهتم كثيرا لهذا الإغراء.. كان يريد أن يقتل جالوت لأن جالوت رجل جبار وظالم ولا يؤمن بالله.. وسمح الملك لداود أن يبارز جالوت..

وتقدم داود بعصاه وخمسة أحجار ومقلاعه (وهو نبلة يستخدمها الرعاة).. تقدم جالوت المدجج بالسلاح والدروع.. وسخر جالوت من داود وأهانه وضحك منه، ووضع داود حجرا قويا في مقلاعه وطوح به في الهواء وأطلق الحجر. فأصاب جالوت فقتله. وبدأت المعركة وانتصر جيش طالوت على جيش جالوت.

جمع الله الملك والنبوة لداود:

بعد فترة أصبح داود -عليه السلم- ملكا لبني إسرائيل، فجمع الله على يديه النبوة والملك مرة أخرى.

وتأتي بعض الروايات لتخبرنا بأن طالوت بعد أن اشتهر نجم داوود أكلت الغيرة قلبه، وحاول قتله، وتستمر الروايات في نسج مثل هذه الأمور. لكننا لا نود الخوض فيها فليس لدينا دليل قوي عليها. ما يهمنا هو انتقال الملك بعد فترة من الزمن إلى داود.

لقد أكرم الله نبيه الكريم بعدة معجزات. لقد أنزل عليه الزبور (وَآتَيْنَا دَاوُودَ زَبُورًا)، وآتاه جمال الصوت، فكان عندما يسبّح، تسبح الجبال والطيور معه، والناس ينظرون. وألان الله في يديه الحديد، حتى قيل أنه كان يتعامل مع الحديد كما كان الناس يتعاملون مع الطين والشمع، وقد تكون هذه الإلانة بمعنى أنه أول من عرف أن الحديد ينصهر بالحرارة. فكان يصنع منه الدروع.

كانت الدروع الحديدية التي يصنعها صناع الدروع ثقيلة ولا تجعل المحارب حرا يستطيع أن يتحرك كما يشاء أو يقاتل كما يريد. فقام داوود بصناعة نوعية جديدة من الدروع. درع يتكون من حلقات حديدية تسمح للمحارب بحرية الحركة، وتحمي جسده من السيوف والفئوس والخناجر.. أفضل من الدروع الموجودة أيامها..

وشد الله ملك داود، جعله الله منصورا على أعدائه دائما.. وجعل ملكه قويا عظيما يخيف الأعداء حتى بغير حرب، وزاد الله من نعمه على داود فأعطاه الحكمة وفصل الخطاب، أعطاه الله مع النبوة والملك حكمة وقدرة على تمييز الحق من الباطل ومعرفة الحق ومساندته.. فأصبح نبيا ملكا قاضيا.

القضايا التي عرضت على داود:

يروي لنا القرآن الكريم بعضا من القضايا التي وردت على داود -عليه السلام.

فلقد جلس داود كعادته يوما يحكم بين الناس في مشكلاتهم.. وجاءه رجل صاحب حقل ومعه رجل آخر..

وقال له صاحب الحقل: سيدي النبي.. إن غنم هذا الرجل نزلت حقلي أثناء الليل، وأكلت كل عناقيد العنب التي كانت فيه.. وقد جئت إليك لتحكم لي بالتعويض..

قال داود لصاحب الغنم: هل صحيح أن غنمك أكلت حقل هذا الرجل؟

قال صاحب الغنم: نعم يا سيدي..

قال داود: لقد حكمت بأن تعطيه غنمك بدلا من الحقل الذي أكلته.

قال سليمان.. وكان الله قد علمه حكمة تضاف إلى ما ورث من والده: عندي حكم آخر يا أبي..

قال داود: قله يا سليمان..

قال سليمان: أحكم بأن يأخذ صاحب الغنم حقل هذا الرجل الذي أكلته الغنم.. ويصلحه له ويزرعه حتى تنمو أشجار العنب، وأحكم لصاحب الحقل أن يأخذ الغنم ليستفيد من صوفها ولبنها ويأكل منه، فإذا كبرت عناقيد الغنم وعاد الحقل سليما كما كان أخذ صاحب الحقل حقله وأعطى صاحب الغنم غنمه..

قال داود: هذا حكم عظيم يا سليمان.. الحمد لله الذي وهبك الحكمة..

وقد ورد في الصحيح قصة أخرى: حَدَّثَنِى زُهَيْرُ بْنُ حَرْبٍ حَدَّثَنِى شَبَابَةُ حَدَّثَنِى وَرْقَاءُ عَنْ أَبِى الزِّنَادِ عَنِ الأَعْرَجِ عَنْ أَبِى هُرَيْرَةَ عَنِ النَّبِىِّ صلى الله عليه وسلم قَالَ « بَيْنَمَا امْرَأَتَانِ مَعَهُمَا ابْنَاهُمَا جَاءَ الذِّئْبُ فَذَهَبَ بِابْنِ إِحْدَاهُمَا . فَقَالَتْ هَذِهِ لِصَاحِبَتِهَا إِنَّمَا ذَهَبَ بِابْنِكِ أَنْتِ . وَقَالَتِ الأُخْرَى إِنَّما ذَهَبَ بِابْنِكِ . فَتَحَاكَمَتَا إِلَى دَاوُدَ فَقَضَى بِهِ لِلْكُبْرَى فَخَرَجَتَا عَلَى سُلَيْمَانَ بْنِ دَاوُدَ عَلَيْهِمَا السَّلاَمُ فَأَخْبَرَتَاهُ فَقَالَ ائْتُونِى بِالسِّكِّينِ أَشُقُّهُ بَيْنَكُمَا . فَقَالَتِ الصُّغْرَى لاَ يَرْحَمُكَ اللَّهُ هُوَ ابْنُهَا . فَقَضَى بِهِ لِلصُّغْرَى ». قَالَ قَالَ أَبُو هُرَيْرَةَ وَاللَّهِ إِنْ سَمِعْتُ بِالسِّكِّينِ قَطُّ إِلاَّ يَوْمَئِذٍ مَا كُنَّا نَقُولُ إِلاَّ الْمُدْيَةَ.

فتنة داود:

وكان داود رغم قربه من الله وحب الله له، يتعلم دائما من الله، وقد علمه الله يوما ألا يحكم أبدا إلا إذا استمع لأقوال الطرفين المتخاصمين.. فيذكر لنا المولى في كتابه الكريم قضية أخرى عرضت على داود عليه السلام.

جلس داود يوما في محرابه الذي يصلي لله ويتعبد فيه، وكان إذا دخل حجرته أمر حراسه ألا يسمحوا لأحد بالدخول عليه أو إزعاجه وهو يصلي.. ثم فوجئ يوما في محرابه بأنه أمام اثنين من الرجال.. وخاف منهما داود لأنهما دخلا رغم أنه أمر ألا يدخل عليه أحد. سألهما داود: من أنتما؟

قال أحد الرجلين: لا تخف يا سيدي.. بيني وبين هذا الرجل خصومة وقد جئناك لتحكم بيننا بالحق.

سأل داود: ما هي القضية؟ قال الرجل الأول: (إِنَّ هَذَا أَخِي لَهُ تِسْعٌ وَتِسْعُونَ نَعْجَةً وَلِيَ نَعْجَةٌ وَاحِدَةٌ). وقد أخذها مني. قال أعطها لي وأخذها مني..

وقال داود بغير أن يسمع رأي الطرف الآخر وحجته: (لَقَدْ ظَلَمَكَ بِسُؤَالِ نَعْجَتِكَ إِلَى نِعَاجِهِ).. وإن كثيرا من الشركاء يظلم بعضهم بعضا إلا الذين آمنوا..

وفوجئ داود باختفاء الرجلين من أمامه.. اختفى الرجلان كما لو كانا سحابة تبخرت في الجو وأدرك داود أن الرجلين ملكان أرسلهما الله إليه ليعلماه درسا.. فلا يحكم بين المتخاصمين من الناس إلا إذا سمع أقوالهم جميعا، فربما كان صاحب التسع والتسعين نعجة معه الحق.. وخر داود راكعا، وسجد لله، واستغفر ربه..

نسجت أساطير اليهود قصصا مريبة حول فتنة داود عليه السلام، وقيل أنه اشتهى امرأة أحد قواد جيشه فأرسله في معركة يعرف من البداية نهايتها، واستولى على امرأته.. وليس أبعد عن تصرفات داود من هذه القصة المختلقة.. إن إنسانا يتصل قلبه بالله، ويتصل تسبيحه بتسبيح الكائنات والجمادات، يستحيل عليه أن يرى أو يلاحظ جمالا بشريا محصورا في وجه امرأة أو جسدها..

وفاته عليه السلام:

عاد داود يعبد الله ويسبحه حتى مات… كان داود يصوم يوما ويفطر يوما.. قال رسول الله محمد بن عبد الله صلى الله عليه وسلم عن داود: "أفضل الصيام صيام داود. كان يصوم يوما ويفطر يوما. وكان يقرأ الزبور بسبعين صوتا، وكانت له ركعة من الليل يبكي فيها نفسه ويبكي ببكائه كل شيء ويشفي بصوته المهموم والمحموم"..

جاء في الحديث الصحيح أن داود عليه السلام كان شديد الغيرة على نساءه، فكانت نساءه في قصر، وحول القصر أسوار، حتى لا يقترب أحد من نساءه. وفي أحد الأيام رأى النسوة رجلا في صحن القصر، فقالوا: من هذا والله لن رآه داود ليبطشنّ به. فبلغ الخبر داود -عليه السلام- فقال للرجل: من أنت؟ وكيف دخلت؟ قال: أنا من لا يقف أمامه حاجز. قال: أنت ملك الموت. فأذن له فأخذ ملك الموت روحه.

مات داود عليه السلام وعمره مئة سنة. وشيع جنازته عشرات الآلاف، فكان محبوبا جدا بين الناس، حتى قيل لم يمت في بني إسرائيل بعد موسى وهارون أحد كان بنو إسرائيل أشد جزعا عليه.. منهم على داود.. وآذت الشمس الناس فدعا سليمان الطير قال: أظلي على داود. فأظلته حتى أظلمت عليه الأرض. وسكنت الريح. وقال سليمان للطير: أظلي الناس من ناحية الشمس وتنحي من ناحية الريح. وأطاعت الطير. فكان ذلك أول ما رآه الناس من ملك سليمان.
number-en: The story of David, peace be upon him
label-en:
About:

God gave him knowledge and wisdom and subjugated to him the mountains and birds that glorified him and made iron for him. He was a sincere and thankful servant of God who fasted one day and broke his fast one day, staying up for half the night, sleeping for a third of it and praying for a sixth of it. God revealed to him the Psalms and he was given a great kingdom, and God commanded him to rule justly.

His biography:

The condition of the children of Israel before David:

Before starting with the story of David, peace be upon him, let us see the conditions that the children of Israel lived in during that period.

Governance has been separated from religion. The last king-prophet was Joshua bin Nun. After him, the kings ruled over the children of Israel and the prophets guided them. The tyranny of the Children of Israel increased, and they were killing the prophets, prophet after prophet, so God imposed upon them kings from among them, oppressive and tyrannical, who subjugated them and oppressed them.

The children of Israel suffered successive defeats, until they lost the ark. In the coffin was a remnant of what the family of Moses and Aaron had left behind. It was said that it contained a remnant of the tablets that God revealed to Moses, his disobedience, and other matters. The children of Israel used to take the ark with them in their battles to gain peace of mind and achieve victory. They spread out and their condition worsened.

In these difficult circumstances, there was a pregnant woman who prayed hard to God to grant her a boy. She gave birth to a boy and named him Ashmuel...which means Ishmael in Hebrew...that is, God heard my supplication...so when he grew up, I sent him to the mosque and handed him over to a righteous man so that he could learn goodness and worship from him. So it was with him, and when he reached his peak, while he was sleeping one night: When a voice came to him from the direction of the mosque, he woke up terrified, thinking that the Sheikh was calling him. Ashmuel rushed to ask him: Did you invite me? The Sheikh thought that he would frighten him, so he said: Yes... sleep... so he slept...

Then the voice called him a second time... and a third time. And pay attention to Gabriel, peace be upon him, calling him: Your Lord has sent you to your people.

Choosing Taloot as king:

The children of Israel went to their Prophet one day.. They asked him: Aren't we oppressed?
He said: Yes..
They said: Aren't we homeless?
He said: Yes..
They said: Send us a king who will gather us under his banner so that we can fight in the name of God and regain our land and glory.
Their Prophet, who was more knowledgeable about them, said: Are you confident of fighting if fighting is prescribed for you?
They said: Why don't we fight for the sake of God, when we were expelled from our homes, our children were displaced, and our situation worsened?
Their Prophet said: God has chosen Taloot as your king. They said: How can he be king over us when he is not a member of the family from which the kings emerge - the sons of Judah - and he is not rich, and there are those among us who are richer than him?
Their Prophet said: God chose him and favored him over you with his knowledge and the strength of his body.
They said: What is the sign of his sovereignty?
Their Prophet said to them: The coffin will be returned to you, decorated by angels.

This miracle happened... and the Torah was returned to them one day... Then Talut's army prepared, and the army marched for a long time until the soldiers felt thirsty... King Taloot said to his soldiers: We will come across a river on the way, so whoever drinks from it should leave the army, and whoever has not tasted it, but only his saliva, should stay with me in the army..

The river came and most of the soldiers drank and left the army. Taloot had prepared this test to know which of the soldiers would obey him and which would disobey him, and to know which of them were strong-willed and could withstand thirst, and which of them were weak-willed and would surrender quickly. Only three hundred and thirteen men remained, but they were all brave.

The number of members of Talut's army was small, and the enemy's army was large and strong. Some of these elites felt that they were weaker than Goliath and his army and said: How do we defeat this mighty army?!

The believers from Taloot’s army said: Victory is not due to equipment and equipment, but rather victory is from God.. (How many a small group has defeated a large group, God willing)... So they made them steadfast.

Goliath appeared in his iron armor and weapons, asking for someone to duel him.. And all of Taloot’s soldiers were afraid of him.. And here a young shepherd, David, emerged from Taloot’s army.. David believed in God, and he knew that faith in God is the true power in this universe, and that what matters is not the abundance of weapons, the size of the body, or the appearance of falsehood.

The king had said: Whoever kills Goliath will become a commander in the army and marry my daughter. David did not care much about this temptation. He wanted to kill Goliath because Goliath is a mighty and unjust man and does not believe in God. The king allowed David to duel Goliath.

David advanced with his staff, five stones, and his slingshot (an arrow used by shepherds)... Goliath advanced, armed with weapons and armor.. Goliath mocked David, insulted him, and laughed at him. David put a strong stone in his slingshot, threw it into the air, and released the stone. He struck Goliath and killed him. The battle began and the army of Taloot defeated the army of Goliath.

God combined kingship and prophecy for David:

After a while, David - peace be upon him - became king of the children of Israel, so God combined prophecy and kingship in his hands once again.

Some narratives tell us that after Taloot became famous, jealousy consumed his heart and he tried to kill him, and narratives continue to spin such matters. But we do not want to delve into it, as we have no strong evidence for it. What concerns us is the transfer of the kingship after a period of time to David.

God honored His noble Prophet with many miracles. The Psalms were revealed to him (And We gave David the Psalms), and the beauty of the voice was given to him, so when he swam, the mountains and birds would swim with him, and the people looked on. God softened iron in his hands, to the point that it was said that he was dealing with iron as people used to deal with clay and wax, and this softening may be in the sense that he was the first to know that iron melts with heat. He used to make armor from it.

The iron armor made by armor makers was heavy and did not make the warrior free to move as he wanted or fight as he wanted. So David manufactured a new type of armor. A shield consisting of iron rings that allows the warrior freedom of movement, and protects his body from swords, axes, and daggers.. better than the shields that existed in those days..

May God strengthen David’s kingdom, may God grant him victory over his enemies always. He made his kingdom strong and great, intimidating the enemies even without war. God increased His blessings upon David, giving him wisdom and decisive speech. God gave him, along with prophecy and kingship, wisdom and the ability to distinguish truth from falsehood, know the truth, and support it... so he became a prophet, king, and judge.

The issues presented to David:

The Holy Qur’an tells us some of the issues that came to David - peace be upon him.

One day, as was his custom, David sat judging people’s problems. A man who owned a field came to him, and another man was with him.

The owner of the field said to him: Mr. Prophet.. This man's sheep came down to my field during the night and ate all the grape clusters that were in it... and I have come to you to award me compensation...

David said to the owner of the sheep: Is it true that your sheep ate this man's field?

The sheep owner said: Yes, sir.

David said: You have decided to give him your sheep instead of the field that you ate.

Solomon said.. As if God had taught him wisdom in addition to what he inherited from his father: I have another wisdom, my father..

Dawud said: Say it, Suleiman.

Solomon said: I rule that the owner of the sheep take this man’s field that the sheep have eaten. And he fixes it for himself and plants it until the grape trees grow, and it is wiser for the owner of the field to take the sheep so that he can benefit from their wool and milk and eat from them. If the bunches of the sheep grow and the field returns healthy as it was, the owner of the field takes his field and gives the owner of the sheep his sheep..

David said: This is a great ruling, Solomon. Praise be to God who gave you wisdom. Another story was mentioned in the Sahih: Zuhair bin Harb told me, Shababah told me, Warqa’ told me, on the authority of Abu al-Zinad, on the authority of al-Araj, on the authority of Abu Hurairah, on the authority of the Prophet, may God bless him and grant him peace. He said, “While two women were with their sons, a wolf came and took the son of one of them.” So this woman said to her friend, “It is your son who has gone away.” The other said: He took your son away. So they brought a ruling to David, and he decided for him to the elders, so they went out to Suleiman bin David, peace be upon them, and told him, and he said, “Bring me a knife and I will cut him open.” Between you. The youngest said, “May God have mercy on you, he is her son.” So he ruled for the minor. He said: Abu Hurairah said: By God, if I had ever heard of a knife except that day, we would not have said anything but a knife.

David's temptation:

David, despite his closeness to God and God’s love for him, was always learning from God, and God taught him one day never to judge unless he listened to the sayings of the two opposing parties. The Lord mentions to us in his noble book another case that was presented to David, peace be upon him.

One day, David sat in his niche where he prayed and worshiped God, and when he entered his room, he ordered his guards not to allow anyone to enter or disturb him while he was praying. Then one day he was surprised in his prayer room that he was in front of two men... and David was afraid of them because they entered even though he had ordered that no one should enter him. David asked them: Who are you?

One of the two men said: Do not be afraid, sir. There is a dispute between me and this man, and we have come to you to judge between us with justice.

David asked: What is the issue? The first man said: (This is my brother. He has ninety-nine ewes, and I have one ewe.) And he took it from me. He said give it to me and take it from me.

Without listening to the other party’s opinion and argument, David said: “He has wronged you by asking your ewe to go to his ewe.” And many of the partners wrong one another except those who believe.

David was surprised by the disappearance of the two men in front of him. The two men disappeared as if they were a cloud that had evaporated in the air, and David realized that the two men were angels sent to him by God to teach him a lesson. He should not judge between disputing people unless he heard all of their sayings. Perhaps the owner of the ninety-nine ewes was on his side. David fell down on his knees, prostrated to God, and asked his Lord for forgiveness.

Jewish legends wove suspicious stories about the temptation of David, peace be upon him. It was said that he lusted after the wife of one of his army commanders, so he sent him into a battle whose end he knew from the beginning, and he seized his wife. Nothing could be further from David’s actions than this fabricated story. A person whose heart is connected to God, and whose praise is connected to the praise of creatures and inanimate objects, would find it impossible for him to see or notice human beauty confined to the face or body of a woman.

His death, peace be upon him:

David returned to worshiping God and praising Him until he died... David used to fast one day and break his fast one day.. The Messenger of God, Muhammad bin Abdullah, may God bless him and grant him peace, said on the authority of David: “The best fast is the fast of David. He used to fast one day and break his fast the next. He used to recite the Psalms with seventy voices, and he used to perform a rak’ah at night in which he would cry to himself, and with his crying he would cry everything out, and he would heal the anxious and feverish people with his voice.”

It is stated in the authentic hadith that David, peace be upon him, was very jealous of his wives, so his wives were in a palace, and around the palace were walls, so that no one would approach his wives. One day, the women saw a man in the courtyard of the palace, and they said: Who is this? By God, David would not have seen him so that he would be angry with him. The news reached David - peace be upon him - and he said to the man: Who are you? How did you get in? He said: I am the one before whom there is no barrier. He said: You are the angel of death. He gave him permission, and the Angel of Death took his soul.

David, peace be upon him, died when he was one hundred years old. His funeral was attended by tens of thousands, and he was very beloved among the people, to the point that it was said that no one among the Children of Israel died after Moses and Aaron for whom the Children of Israel were more anxious than they were for David. And the sun hurt the people, so Solomon called the birds and said: Shall my shade over David. So I shaded him until the earth became dark over him. And the wind calmed down. Solomon said to the birds: Shade the people from the direction of the sun and step aside from the direction of the wind. And the bird obeyed. This was the first thing people saw of King Solomon.
